Proceed.assistantfinal**(a)   Definitions**

* **Helmholtz free‑energy**
\[
F(T,V,N,\dots)\equiv U-TS ,
\]
where  

\(U\) – internal energy,  
\(S\) – entropy,  
\(T\) – absolute temperature,   
\(V\) – volume, \(N\) … other extensive variables kept fixed.

In the canonical ensemble (\(T,V,N\) fixed)

\[
\boxed{\,F=-k_{\!B}\,T\;\ln Z\,}
\tag{1}
\]

with \(k_{B}\) the Boltzmann constant.

---

* **Canonical partition function (classical)**  

For a classical many–particle system whose Hamiltonian is \(H(p,q;V)\),

\[
\boxed{
Z(T,V,N)=\frac{1}{h^{3N}N!}\int 
      {\rm d}^{3N}p\,
      {\rm d}^{3N}q\;
      \exp[-\beta H(p,q;V)]
     }
\qquad(\beta\equiv 1/k_{B}T)
\tag{2}
\]

The integral runs over all phase‑space coordinates \((p,q)\); the factor
\(h^{3N}N!\) removes indistinguishability and makes \(Z\) dimensionless.

Equation (1) links the macroscopic thermodynamic potential \(F\) to the microscopic sum over states embodied in \(Z\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

**(b)   Heat capacity at constant volume**

From Eq.(1),
\[
\ln Z=-\frac{F}{k_{B}T}.
\]

Differentiating with respect to \(\beta\;(=\!1/k_{B}T)\) one obtains the average
internal energy,

\[
U\equiv\langle E\rangle=
-\frac{\partial\ln Z}{\partial\beta}
=k_{B}T^{2}\,\frac{\partial\ln Z}{\partial T},
\tag{3}
\]

(the last equality follows from \(\displaystyle\frac{{\rm d}}{{\rm d}T}=-
\frac{1}{k_{B}T^{2}}\frac{{\rm d}}{{\rm d}\beta}\)).  

By definition the specific heat at constant volume is

\[
c_{v}\equiv\Bigl(\frac{\partial U}{\partial T}\Bigr)_{V}.
\tag{4}
\]

Insert (3) into (4):

\[
\begin{aligned}
c_{v}&=\frac{\partial }{\partial T}
        \bigl[k_{B}T^{2}\tfrac{\partial\ln Z}{\partial T}\bigr]_{V}\\[2mm]
    &=k_{B}\Bigl[2T\tfrac{\partial\ln Z}{\partial T}
                 +T^{2}\tfrac{\partial^{2}\ln Z}{\partial T^{2}}
            \Bigr]_{V}.
\end{aligned}
\tag{5}
\]

Introduce the auxiliary quantity \(G(T)\equiv T\ln Z\).
Its first and second derivatives are

\[
G'(T)=\ln Z+T\frac{\partial\ln Z}{\partial T},\qquad
G''(T)=2\frac{\partial\ln Z}{\partial T}
       +T\frac{\partial^{2}\ln Z}{\partial T^{2}} .
\]

Multiplying the latter by \(k_{B}T\) reproduces exactly the bracket in (5):
\[
k_{B}T\,G''(T)=k_{B}\Bigl[2T\frac{\partial\ln Z}{\partial T}
                       +T^{2}\frac{\partial^{2}\ln Z}{\partial T^{2}}
                  \Bigr].
\]

Hence

\[
\boxed{%
c_{v}=k_{B}T\,
      \Biggl[\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial T^{2}}
             \bigl(T\ln Z\bigr)\Biggr]_{V}
     } .
\tag{6}
\]

This is the required expression.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

**(c)   Two‑level classical system**

Assume the system possesses only two possible total energies,
\(E_{0}\) (ground level) and \(E_{1}>E_{0}\) (excited level).  
The canonical partition function reads

\[
\boxed{%
Z(T)=e^{-\beta E_{0}}+e^{-\beta E_{1}},\qquad
\beta\equiv\frac{1}{k_{B}T}
}.
\tag{7}
\]

It is convenient to shift the zero of energy so that \(E_{0}=0\);
let \(\Delta\equiv E_{1}-E_{0}>0\).  Then

\[
Z=1+e^{-\beta\Delta}.
\tag{8}
\]

Probability of finding the system in the excited state:
\[
p_{1}=\frac{e^{-\beta\Delta}}{1+e^{-\beta\Delta}}
      =\frac{1}{e^{\beta\Delta}+1},
\qquad
p_{0}=1-p_{1}.
\]

Average energy

\[
\langle E\rangle =\Delta\,p_{1}
                =\frac{\Delta}{e^{\beta\Delta}+1}.
\tag{9}
\]

Using either \(c_{v}=(\partial\langle E\rangle/\partial T)_{V}\) or the fluctuation
formula \(c_{v}=({\langle E^{2}\rangle-\langle E\rangle^{2}})
               /\!(k_{B}T^{2})\) gives

\[
\begin{aligned}
c_{v}
&=k_{B}\,\beta^{2}\,\Delta^{2}\,p_{1}(1-p_{1})
\\[1mm]
&=k_{B}\left(\frac{\Delta}{k_{B}T}\right)^{\!2}
   \frac{e^{\beta\Delta}}{\bigl(1+e^{\beta\Delta}\bigr)^{2}} .
\end{aligned}
\tag{10}
\]

Equivalently, writing \(x\equiv\beta\Delta=\Delta/(k_{B}T)\),

\[
\boxed{%
c_{v}=k_{B}\,x^{2}\,
      \frac{e^{x}}{(1+e^{x})^{2}},
\qquad x=\frac{\Delta}{k_{B}T}
}.
\tag{11}
\]

These formulas reduce correctly to \(c_{v}\to0\) when \(T\rightarrow0\) (all systems
in the ground state) and to \(c_{v}\to0\) again for \(T\rightarrow\infty\) (equal
population of the two levels).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
**Final summary**

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{ll}
\text{(a)} & F=-k_{B}T\ln Z ,\quad
              Z=\dfrac{1}{h^{3N}N!}\!\int\!dp\,dq\;
                    e^{-\beta H(p,q)} \\[4pt]
\text{(b)} & c_{v}=k_{B}T\,
           \displaystyle\Bigg[\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial T^{2}}
                     \bigl(T\ln Z\bigr)\Bigg]_{V} \\[6pt]
\text{(c)} &
\displaystyle Z=e^{-\beta E_{0}}+e^{-\beta E_{1}},\qquad
c_{v}=k_{B}\!
\left(\frac{E_{1}-E_{0}}{k_{B}T}\right)^{\!2}
\frac{e^{(E_{1}-E_{0})/(k_{B}T)}}{\bigl[1+
e^{(E_{1}-E_{0})/(k_{B}T)}\bigr]^{2}} .
\end{array}
}
\]

For the rubber band the natural variables are the temperature \(T\) and the length \(x\).
Its fundamental relation is  

\[
dE=T\,dS+t\,dx,
\qquad  
t=A\,T\!\left(\frac{x}{l_{0}}-\frac{l_{0}^{2}}{x^{2}}\right),
\tag{1}
\]

so that  

\[
\Bigl(\frac{\partial E}{\partial T}\Bigr) _x=c_{x},\qquad   
\Bigl(\frac{\partial E}{\partial x}\Bigr) _T=
T\Bigl(\frac{\partial S}{\partial x}\Bigr) _T+t .
\tag{2}
\]

Introduce the Helmholtz potential \(F=E-TS\):

\[
dF=-S\,dT+t\,dx,\qquad    
S=-\bigl(\partial F/\partial T\bigr)_x,\;\;
t=\bigl(\partial F/\partial x\bigr)_T .
\]

Consequently the Maxwell relation reads  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\Bigl(\frac{\partial S}{\partial x}\Bigr)_T
   =-\Bigl(\frac{\partial t}{\partial T}\Bigr)_x } .
\tag{3}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (a)

#### 1. \( (\partial E/\partial x)_T\)

From (1),

\[
\Bigl(\frac{\partial t}{\partial T}\Bigr)_x
      =A\!\left(\frac{x}{l_{0}}-\frac{l_{0}^{2}}{x^{2}}\right)
      =\frac{t}{T}.
\]

Using the Maxwell relation (3),

\[
\Bigl(\frac{\partial S}{\partial x}\Bigr)_T
     =-\frac{t}{T},
\]
hence from (2)

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\Bigl(\frac{\partial E}{\partial x}\Bigr)_T
    =T\Bigl(\frac{\partial S}{\partial x}\Bigr)_T+t
    =-t+t=0 } .
\]

---

#### 2. \( (\partial c_x /\partial x)_T\)

Because \(c_x=(\partial E/\partial T)_x\),

\[
\Bigl(\frac{\partial c_x}{\partial x}\Bigr)_T
   =\frac{\partial}{\partial x}
        \Bigl[\Bigl(\frac{\partial E}{\partial T}\Bigr)_x\Bigr]_T
   =\frac{\partial}{\partial T}
        \Bigl[\Bigl(\frac{\partial E}{\partial x}\Bigr)_T\Bigr]_x
   =\frac{\partial}{\partial T}(0)=0 .
\]

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\Bigl(\frac{\partial c_x}{\partial x}\Bigr)_T=0 } .
\]

Thus the heat‑capacity at fixed length does **not** depend on the length.

---

#### 3. Heat capacity \(c_x(x,T)\)

Experimentally one finds that at the special length \(x=l_{0}\)

\[
c_x(l_{0},T)=K\quad\text{(independent of \(T\)).}
\]

Since \((\partial c_x/\partial x)_T=0\), the above value holds for any
\(x\); moreover the lack of \(T\)-dependence follows from the next step.
Hence  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle c_x(x,T)=K } .
\]

---

#### 4. Internal energy \(E(x,T)\)

With \(c_x=(\partial E/\partial T)_x=K\) we obtain  

\[
E(x,T)=K\,T+C,
\]

the integration “constant’’ being independent of \(T\) and, owing to
\((\partial E/\partial x)_T=0\), also independent of \(x\). Choosing the
zero of energy at \(T=0\) gives \(C=0\):

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle E(x,T)=K\,T } .
\]

---

#### 5. Entropy \(S(x,T)\)

First use \(c_x=T(\partial S/\partial T)_x\):

\[
K=T\Bigl(\frac{\partial S}{\partial T}\Bigr)_x
\Longrightarrow
\Bigl(\frac{\partial S}{\partial T}\Bigr)_x=\frac{K}{T}.
\]

Integrating with respect to \(T\),

\[
S(x,T)=K\ln T+g(x),
\tag{4}
\]

where \(g(x)\) is yet undetermined.  
Employ the Maxwell relation obtained before,

\[
\Bigl(\frac{\partial S}{\partial x}\Bigr)_T
       =-\frac{t}{T}=-
          A\!\left(\frac{x}{l_{0}}
                 -\frac{l_{0}^{2}}{x^{2}}\right) .
\]

Differentiating (4) with respect to \(x\) gives \(\partial g/\partial x\);
therefore  

\[
\frac{dg}{dx}= -A\!
               \left(\frac{x}{l_{0}}
                     -\frac{l_{0}^{2}}{x^{2}}\right) .
\]

Integration over \(x\) yields  

\[
g(x)= -A\!\int\!\left(
                \frac{x}{l_{0}}-\frac{l_{0}^{2}}{x^{2}}
              \right)dx
     =-A\!\left(\frac{x^{2}}{2l_{0}}+\frac{l_{0}^{2}}{x}\right)+\text{const}.
\]

Choosing the additive constant conveniently, the entropy becomes  

\[
\boxed{
S(x,T)=K\ln T
      -A\!\left(\frac{x^{2}}{2l_{0}}+
                \frac{l_{0}^{2}}{x}\right)} .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (b)  Adiabatic stretching

An adiabatic (reversible) transformation satisfies \(\Delta S=0\):
\(S_{\mathrm{i}}=S_{\mathrm{f}}\).

* Initial state : \(x_i=l_{0},\; T_i=T_{0}\)

\[
S_i=K\ln T_{0}-A\!\left(\frac{l_{0}^{2}}{2l_{0}}+
                       \frac{l_{0}^{2}}{l_{0}}\right)
    =K\ln T_{0}-A\frac{3}{2}l_{0}.
\]

* Final state : \(x_f=1.5\,l_{0},\; T_f=?\)

\[
S_f=K\ln T_{f}
    -A\!\left(
           \frac{(1.5\,l_{0})^{2}}{2l_{0}}+
           \frac{l_{0}^{2}}{1.5\,l_{0}}
         \right)
    =K\ln T_{f}
    -A\frac{43}{24}l_{0}.
\]

Setting \(S_i=S_f\),

\[
K\ln T_{0}-\frac32Al_{0}=K\ln T_{f}-\frac{43}{24}Al_{0},
\]

which gives  

\[
K\ln T_{f}=K\ln T_{0}+ \frac{7}{24}Al_{0}.
\]

Finally  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
T_{f}=T_{0}\exp\!\left(\frac{7Al_{0}}{24K}\right)} .
\]

The temperature rises during the adiabatic stretch because work done on
the band increases its internal energy while the entropy stays unchanged.

Below \(100\;\mathrm {mK}\) helium‑3 exists either as a normal Fermi liquid (\(L\)) or as a quantum crystal (\(S\)).  
Because the molar volume of the liquid is always **larger** than that of the solid  

\[
\Delta V\equiv V_{L}-V_{S}>0 ,
\tag{1}
\]

an applied hydrostatic pressure favours the dense phase (the solid).   
If a sample contains both phases, a modest increase of the external pressure can force part of the solid to disappear (it “melts’’) or, conversely, make part of the liquid crystallise, according to what keeps the total Gibbs free energy minimum.

The driving force for the phase change is the **entropy difference** between the two phases.  
For the liquid we assume the usual quasiparticle form  

\[
S_{L}(T)=\gamma\,R\,T ,\qquad 
\gamma\simeq 4.6\ {\rm K^{-1}},
\tag{2}
\]

whereas the solid carries essentially only the nuclear‑spin contribution  

\[
S_{S}=R\ln 2\;(={\rm const}) .
\tag{3}
\]

Consequently the entropy jump at the liquid–solid coexistence line is  

\[
\boxed{\;
\Delta S(T)\equiv S_{L}-S_{S}=R(\,\gamma T-\ln 2\,)
\;}
\tag{4}
\]

and the corresponding latent heat is  

\[
L(T)=T\Delta S=T\,R(\gamma T-\ln 2).
\tag{5}
\]

---

### 1.   Shape of the \(p\!-\!T\) coexistence curve  

From the Clapeyron relation  

\[
\frac{{\rm d}P}{{\rm d}T}= \frac{\Delta S}{\Delta V},
\tag{6}
\]

and using (1)–(4),

\[
\frac{{\rm d}P}{{\rm d}T}= 
\frac{R}{\Delta V}\bigl(\gamma T-\ln 2\bigr).
\tag{7}
\]

Two regimes appear :

| Temperature | Sign of \(\Delta S\) | Slope \({\rm d}P/{\rm d}T\) |
|-------------|----------------------|----------------------------|
| \(T>\displaystyle T_{\times}\equiv\frac{\ln 2}{\gamma}\approx 0.15\;{\rm K}\) | \(\Delta S>0\) | Positive |
| \(T<T_{\times}\) | \(\Delta S<0\) | Negative |

Thus the coexistence line starts at the **triple point** (roughly \(P\!\approx\!30\,$bar, \(T\!=\!0\)), rises with a positive slope up to \(T_{\times}\), reaches a maximum at \(T_{\times}\) and then bends back toward lower pressures.

```
      |______/

      |  \_____\
      +--------------> T

```


--- 

### 2.   How pressure produces cooling  

Consider a sealed vessel that already holds a **two‑phase mixture** at a temperature \(T_0>T_\times\) and a pressure \(P_0\) lying somewhere on the coexistence curve.  
An additional pressure increment \(\delta P\) is applied **rapidly**, faster than any heat flow to the environment, i.e. the process is **adiabatic** (\(Q=0\)).  

During the subsequent relaxation the excess pressure makes a fraction \(x\) of the solid transform into liquid (because the liquid occupies a larger volume, it relieves the imposed stress).  
The required amount of heat is precisely the latent heat needed for the phase change,

\[
\underbrace{x\,L(T)}_{\text{heat taken from the fluid}}=
-x\,T\,\Delta S .
\tag{8}
\]

Since for our working regime \(\Delta S>0\) [Eq.(4)], the term on the right‑hand side is **negative** : the system must absorb heat from its own degrees of freedom in order to supply the latent heat. Consequently the temperature drops:

\[
\Delta T = -\frac{x\,L(T)}{C_{\text{tot}}},
\tag{9}
\]
\(C_{\text tot}}\) being the total heat capacity of the liquid plus the nuclear‑spin reservoir of the solid.  

In words: *pressurising a liquid–solid mixture forces part of the solid to melt; the melting consumes the relatively large entropy carried by the liquid, thereby extracting thermal energy from the whole sample and lowering its temperature.*

When the pressure is released again the reverse happens (part of the liquid re‑crystallises) and the temperature returns close to its original value, allowing the cycle to be repeated many times—a practical **mechanical refrigerator** known as the “adiabatic‐compression” or “pressure‑driven” cooler for \(^3\)He.

---

Cooling stops once the entropy of the liquid falls below that of the solid, i.e. when \(\Delta S\rightarrow 0\). From (4)

\[

\frac{0.693}{4.6\ {\rm K^{-1}}}\approx 0.15\ {\rm K}}
\tag{10}
\]

At temperatures lower than \(T_{\min }\) the solid possesses the larger entropy; any further melting would now **release** heat rather than absorb it, so the mechanism ceases to provide cooling. In real devices one therefore operates just above \(0.15\;\mathrm{K}\) and combines the pressure stage with other techniques (e.g. dilution refrigeration) to reach the micro‑kelvin regime.

---

Applying pressure to a pre‑existing liquid–solid mixture of \(^3\)He forces part of the solid to melt because the liquid has the larger molar volume.  The melting consumes the latent heat \(L=T(S_L-S_S)=TR(\gamma T-\ln 2)\).  As long as the temperature satisfies  

\[
\boxed{T>\frac{\ln 2}{\gamma}\;\approx\;0.15\ {\rm K}}, 
\]

the entropy of the liquid exceeds that of the solid \((\Delta S>0)\) and the latent heat is drawn from the sample itself, producing a drop in temperature.  On a \(p\!-\!T\) plot the coexistence line follows the Clapeyron law  

\[
\frac{{\rm d}P}{{\rm d}T}= \frac{R}{\Delta V}\bigl(\gamma T-\ln 2\bigr),
\]  

rising with a positive slope for \(T>T_{\times}\) and bending over to a negative slope below \(T_{\times}\).  By cycling the pressure around the region \(T\gtrsim T_{\times}\) one obtains a reversible mechanical refrigerating action for \(^3\)He.

---

### (a) Third law of thermodynamics  

The *third law* may be stated in two equivalent ways  

1. **Nernst’s formulation:**  
   For any pure substance the entropy \(S(T)\) tends to a universal constant (conventionally taken as zero) when the absolute temperature goes to zero,
   \[
   \lim_{T\to 0}\,S(T)=S_0,\qquad S_0\equiv 0 .
   \]
2. **Unattainability formulation (Planck‑Einstein):**  
   It is impossible, by any finite number of reversible processes, to reduce the temperature of a system to exactly \(T=0\,{\rm K}\).

Consequences: all perfect crystals have a unique ground state (\(\Omega=1\)), the specific heat vanishes as \(T\rightarrow0\), and the absolute scale of entropy becomes well defined.

---

### (b) Physical meaning of a negative absolute temperature  

In statistical mechanics the temperature follows from the fundamental relation  

\[
\frac{1}{T}= \left(\frac{\partial S}{\partial U}\right)_ {V,N}.
\]

If the density of accessible microstates \(\Omega(U)\) first increases with internal energy \(U\) (as usual) but later **decreases** after reaching a maximal value, the derivative \(\partial S/\partial U=\partial\ln\Omega /\partial U\) changes sign. In the region where \(\Omega\) decreases, the slope is negative and therefore  

\[
T < 0 .
\]

A negative temperature therefore corresponds to a **population–inverted** situation: high‑energy states are occupied more often than low‑energy ones. Because adding energy reduces the number of available states, the system “cools” when heated—its entropy falls while its energy rises.

> **Does this violate the third law?** No.  
The third law concerns the limit \(T\rightarrow0^{+}\); it says nothing about what happens at very high energies. A system with a bounded energy spectrum can possess a highest possible energy \(U_{\max }\). As \(U\to U_{\max }\) the temperature formally tends to \(-0\) (i.e., \(T\to-\infty\)). The unattainability clause still holds: you cannot pass continuously from a positive to a negative temperature without crossing an **infinitely hot** point (\(T=+\infty\)) where the entropy reaches its maximum. Hence there is no contradiction with the third law.

One classic laboratory realisation uses **nuclear or electronic spin ensembles in a strong magnetic field**:

| System | How the inversion is created |
|--------|------------------------------|
| Spin‑½ nuclei/electrons placed in a static magnetic field \(B\). | First polarize the spins at a very low positive temperature (most occupy the lowest Zeeman level). Then apply a rapid radio‑frequency pulse that flips many spins, producing a surplus in the upper Zeeman level – i.e. a population inversion. After the pulse the spin subsystem equilibrates internally (via dipolar interactions) faster than it exchanges energy with the lattice, yielding a quasi‑steady state described by a **negative spin temperature**. |

Other modern examples are ultra‑cold atomic gases trapped in optical lattices where the kinetic‐energy band structure is engineered to be bounded; after a sudden change of tunnelling parameters the momentum distribution can become inverted, corresponding to \(T<0\).

N =\int_{0}^{\infty}\! \frac{g(\varepsilon)}{e^{\beta(\varepsilon-\mu)}-1}\,
        {\rm d}\varepsilon .
\tag{1}
\]

Introduce the fugacity \(z=e^{\beta\mu}<1\) and use the expansion  

\[
\frac{1}{e^{\beta\varepsilon}/z-1}= \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}z^{\,n} e^{-n\beta\varepsilon}.
\]

Carrying out the integration yields the familiar result expressed through the polylogarithm function  

\[
\boxed{
   \frac{N}{V}= \lambda _T^{-d}\;
                g_{d/2}(z)},\qquad   
    \lambda_T=\sqrt{\frac{2\pi\hbar^{2}}{mk_B T}},
\quad    
    g_\alpha(z)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{z^{\,n}}{n^\alpha } .
\tag{2}
\]

---

### Condition for condensation

A macroscopic population of the zero‑momentum mode appears when we try to increase the density while keeping the temperature fixed until the fugacity reaches its maximal allowed value \(z\to 1^{-}\) (\(\mu\rightarrow 0\)). At this point Eq.(2) becomes  

\[
\left.\frac{N}{V}\right|_{\max}= \lambda_T^{-d}\; \underbrace{g_{d/2}(1)}_
          {=\;\zeta(d/2)},
\tag{3}
\]

where \(\zeta\) denotes Riemann’s zeta‑function. A *finite* maximum exists only if \(\zeta(d/2)\) itself is finite, i.e. iff  

\[
\frac{d}{2}>1\Longleftrightarrow d>2 .
\]

Consequences:

| Dimension | Exponent in DOS \(\displaystyle g(\varepsilon)\propto\varepsilon^{\frac{d}{2}-1}\) | Critical exponent in (2) | Behaviour of \(\zeta(d/2)\) |
|-----------|---------------------------------------------------|--------------------------|--------------------------------|
| \(d=3\)   | \(\varepsilon^{1/2}\)                              | \(g_{3/2}(z)\)           | \(\zeta(3/2)<\infty\) – **BEC possible** |
| \(d=2\)   | \(\varepsilon^{0}\) (constant)                     | \(g_{1}(z)\)             | \(\zeta(1)\) diverges (logarithmically) – **no finite \(T_c\)** |
| \(d=1\)   | \(\varepsilon^{-1/2}\)                             | \(g_{1/2}(z)\)            | \(\zeta(1/2)\) divergent – **no finite \(T_c\)** |

Hence, for a **uniform, non‑interacting Bose gas**

* **Three dimensions:** a genuine Bose‑Einstein condensation takes place at a finite critical temperature \(T_c\).
* **Two dimensions:** as \(z\!\uparrow\!1\) the required density diverges logarithmically; therefore no finite-temperature phase transition into a macroscopically occupied ground state exists.
* **One dimension:** the needed density diverges even more strongly; again no condensation at any non‑zero temperature.

These results agree with the Mermin–Wagner–Hohenberg theorem, which forbids spontaneous breaking of continuous symmetries (such as global U(1) gauge symmetry associated with a condensate) in systems with short‑range interactions in \(d\le 2\) at finite temperature.

---

### What changes in a trapping potential?

If the particles are placed in an external confinement—most commonly an isotropic harmonic oscillator,

\[
V({\bf r})=\tfrac12 m\omega^{2}r^{2},
\]

the single‑particle spectrum becomes discrete:
\(E_{n_x,n_y,n_z}= \hbar\omega(n_x+n_y+n_z+3/2)\).  
Counting states now gives an *effective* density of states proportional to \(\varepsilon^{d-1}\) rather than \(\varepsilon^{d/2-1}\). Repeating the calculation leads to

\[
\frac{N}{\textstyle\prod_i L_i}= \biggl(\frac{k_BT}{\hbar\omega}\biggr)^{d}\!
                                 g_{d}(z),
\]

and the convergence criterion turns into \(d>0\); consequently a finite “critical” temperature exists even for \(d=1\) and \(d=2\) in a harmonic trap. This is precisely what has been observed experimentally: quasi‑condensation in highly anisotropic traps behaves as a true BEC for practical purposes, although strict off‑diagonal long‑range order remains absent in the thermodynamic limit.

---

## Summary

*For a homogeneous ideal Bose gas*:  
- **3 D** ⇒ Bose‑Einstein condensation at a finite \(T_c\).  
- **2 D** & **1 D** ⇒ No condensation at any non‑zero temperature; the would‑be critical density diverges because the polylogarithm \(g_{d/2}(1)\) is infinite for \(d\le 2\).

*With a confining potential*, the discreteness of the spectrum modifies the counting of states such that a macroscopic ground‑state occupancy can appear even in effectively two‑ or one‑dimensional geometries.

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{c}
\text{Uniform ideal Bose gas condenses only for } d>2\\[2pt]
\text{(i.e. three dimensions).}\\[6pt]
\text{In 2D and 1D the necessary density diverges }\Rightarrow\text{no BEC.}
\end{array}}
\]

Let's craft response.assistantfinal**Step‑by‑step reasoning**

1. **First‑law expressions for a closed system**
   *At constant volume*  
   \[
   \delta Q_{V}=dU=C_{V}\,dT .
   \]
   
   *At constant pressure* we use the definition of enthalpy \(H\equiv U+pV\):  

   \[
   \delta Q_{P}=dH=C_{P}\,dT .
   \]

2. **Relation between \(C_{P}\) and \(C_{V}\)**  

   Differentiate the enthalpy:
   \[
   dH=dU+d(pV)=C_{V}\,dT+\underbrace{\bigl[p\,dV+V\,dp\bigr]}_{\text{work term}} .
   \]

   For a process carried out at **constant external pressure**, \(dp=0\); therefore  

   \[
   dH=C_{V}\,dT+p\,dV .
   \]

3. **Use the ideal–gas equation**  

   An ideal gas obeys \(pV=nRT\Rightarrow p\,dV+nR\,dT=p\,dV\) (since \(n,R,T\) are scalars). Solving for the differential work term:

   \[
   p\,dV=nR\,dT .
   \]

   Substituting into the expression for \(dH\):

   \[
   dH=C_{V}\,dT+nR\,dT=(C_{V}+R)\,dT .
   \]

   But also \(dH=C_{P}\,dT\). Hence  

   \[
   \boxed{C_{P}-C_{V}=R } ,
   \]
   i.e. the excess heat capacity at constant pressure exactly equals the **ideal‑gas constant**.

4. **Numerical values**

   | Unit system                              | Symbol      | Value |
   |------------------------------------------|-------------|-------|
   | Per mole (universal)                     | \(R\)       | \(8.314\;\mathrm{J~mol^{-1}K^{-1}}\) |
   | Per kilogram (specific gas constant)    | \(R_s=c_{p}-c_{v}\) | varies with molecular weight |

   For a typical “simple” gas such as **dry air** (\(M\simeq28.97\;\rm g\,mol^{-1}\)) :

   \[
   R_s=\frac{R}{M}
        =\frac{8.314\;\rm J\,mol^{-1}K^{-1}}
               {0.02897\;\rm kg\,mol^{-1}}
        \approx 2.87\times10^{2}\;\rm J\,kg^{-1}K^{-1}.
   \]

   Thus,
   \[
   c_{p}-c_{v}\;\approx\;2.9\times10^{2}\ {\rm J\,kg^{-1}K^{-1}}
   \quad(\text{for air}),
   \]
   while any other simple mono‑/di‑atomic gas will have essentially the same **per‑mass** number when expressed through its own specific gas constant \(R_s\).

5. **Physical origin of the difference**

   Heating a gas at **constant volume** supplies only the internal‑energy increase \(dU\). No mechanical work is performed because the boundaries do not move.

   When heating at **constant pressure**, the gas expands against the surrounding atmospheric pressure. Part of the supplied heat must therefore go into doing **\(p\,dV\) work** (the “expansion work”) besides raising the internal energy. That additional energetic requirement is precisely the work needed to displace the surroundings, quantified by \(p\,dV = nR\,dT\). Consequently,

   \[
   c_{p}=c_{v}+R_s .
   \]

---

### Final Answer

For an ideal gas  

\[
\boxed{c_{p}-c_{v}=R},
\]

where  

* \(R = 8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\!\,\text{K}^{-1}\) (universal) or  
* \(R_s = \displaystyle\frac{R}{M}\) (specific, e.g. \(≈2.9×10^2\;\text{J kg}^{-1}\!\,\text{K}^{-1}\) for air).

The difference arises because at constant pressure part of the added heat does work expanding the gas against the ambient pressure, whereas at constant volume no work is performed. This extra work term is exactly the ideal‑gas constant \(R\).

assistantfinal**(a) Critical point**

The **critical point** of a substance is the terminal point of the liquid‑vapour coexistence curve on a \(p\!-\!T\) diagram.  
At this state (\(p_{\rm c},\,T_{\rm c}\)) the densities of the liquid and the vapour become identical, surface tension vanishes and the two phases can no longer be distinguished. Above \(p_{\rm c}\) and/or \(T_{\rm c}\) there exists only a single homogeneous fluid (“supercritical” fluid).

---

**(b) Triple point**

A **triple point** is the unique combination of pressure and temperature at which three different phases of a pure substance (normally solid, liquid and vapour) coexist in thermodynamic equilibrium. It lies at the intersection of the three coexistence lines on the phase diagram.

Ok write final response.assistantfinalIn the canonical ensemble the probability of finding the system in micro‑state \(s\) with energy  
\(E_s\) is  

\[
p_s=\frac{e^{-\beta E_s}}{Z(\beta)},\qquad 
\beta\equiv\frac{1}{k_{\!B}T},
\]
where  

\[
Z(\beta)=\sum_{s}e^{-\beta E_s}
\]

is the partition function.   
All thermodynamic averages are taken with this weight,
for example  

\[
\langle E\rangle =\sum_{s}E_s p_s .
\tag{1}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1. Express \(\langle E\rangle\) through the partition function  

From (1),

\[
\langle E\rangle=
\frac{\displaystyle\sum_{s}E_se^{-\beta E_s}}
      {\displaystyle\sum_{s}e^{-\beta E_s}}
   =-\frac{\partial }{\partial\beta}\ln Z .
\tag{2}
\]

(The last equality follows from differentiating \(\ln Z\) with respect to \(\beta\).)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2. Differentiate \(\langle E\rangle\) with respect to temperature  

The definition of the constant–volume heat capacity is  

\[
C_V=\Bigl(\frac{\partial\langle E\rangle}{\partial T}\Bigr)_{N,V}.
\]

Because \(\beta=1/(k_BT)\),  

\[
\frac{\partial}{\partial T}= \frac{{\rm d}\beta}{{\rm d}T}\,\frac{\partial}{\partial\beta}
        =-\frac{1}{k_B T^{2}}\;\frac{\partial}{\partial\beta}.
\]

Using (2),

\[
C_V=-\,\frac{1}{k_B T^{2}}\;
     \frac{\partial\langle E\rangle}{\partial\beta}.
\tag{3}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3. Evaluate \(\displaystyle\frac{\partial\langle E\rangle}{\partial\beta}\)

Write \(\langle E\rangle\) explicitly with the probabilities \(p_s\):

\[
\langle E\rangle =\sum_{s}E_sp_s ,\qquad    
p_s=\frac{e^{-\beta E_s}}{Z}.
\]

Differentiating,

\[
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial\langle E\rangle}{\partial\beta}
&=\sum_{s}E_s\frac{\partial p_s}{\partial\beta}\\[2mm]
&=\sum_{s}E_s\biggl[-E_s p_s-
                 p_s\!\left(-\frac{\partial\ln Z}{\partial\beta}\right)
                \biggr] \\[2mm]
&= -\sum_{s}E_s^{2}p_s+\langle E\rangle\sum_{s}E_sp_s\\[2mm]
&= -\langle E^{2}\rangle+ \langle E\rangle^{2}
   =-\,\bigl\langle\,(E-\langle E\rangle )^{2}\bigr\rangle .
\end{aligned}
\tag{4}
\]

Equation (4) shows that the derivative of the mean energy with respect to \(\beta\) equals minus the **variance** of the energy.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4. Insert Eq.(4) into Eq.(3)

\[
C_V=-\frac{1}{k_B T^{2}}\bigl[-\langle (E-\langle E\rangle)^{2}\rangle\bigr]
    =\frac{1}{k_B T^{2}}\,
      \bigl\langle (E-\langle E\rangle)^{2}\bigr\rangle .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
## Result

Thus, within the canonical ensemble the constant‑volume heat capacity is proportional to the mean‑square fluctuation of the total energy:

\[
\boxed{
C_V=\frac{1}{k_{\! B}T^{2}}\,
       \big\langle\big(E-\langle E\rangle\big)^{2}\big\rangle }
\]

which is precisely the desired relationship. The same equation may be written compactly as  

\[
k_{\!B}T^{2}C_V = \mathrm{Var}(E).
\]

For an isotropic gas of massless particles travelling with speed \(c\),

* averaging over all directions (\(\langle\cos ^2\theta\rangle =1/3\)) gives a factor \(1/3\).

If the total energy contained in a volume \(V\) is \(U\), the energy density is  

\[
u\equiv\frac{U}{V}.
\]

\[
p =\frac13\,u =\boxed{\displaystyle p=\frac{U}{3V}} .
\]

**(b) Temperature dependence of the energy density**

Only the variables **temperature** \(T\) and **volume** \(V\) describe a photon gas
(the photon number is not conserved).   
Write the internal energy as  

\[
U = u(T)\,V ,\qquad u(T)=\text{energy density}.
\]

---

### Step 1 – Thermodynamic identities  

First law (for reversible changes):

\[
dU = T\,dS - p\,dV .
\tag{1}
\]

Second law (definition of entropy):

\[
dS = \frac{dU + p\,dV}{T}. 
\tag{2}
\]

Insert the equation of state found in part (a), \(p=u/3\), and express
\(dU\) through \(u\):

\[
dU = V\,du + u\,dV .
\tag{3}
\]

Substituting (3) into (1) gives  

\[
V\,du + u\,dV = T\,dS-\frac{u}{3}\,dV ,
\]
or equivalently  

\[
T\,dS = V\,du+\Big(u+\frac{u}{3}\Big)dV=
V\,du+\frac43\,u\,dV .
\tag{4}
\]

Because the system is **extensive**, the fundamental Euler relation holds
(without a chemical‑potential term):

\[
U = T S - p V .
\tag{5}
\]

Using \(p=u/3\) and \(U=uV\),

\[
uV = T S -\frac{u}{3}V\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
TS = \frac{4}{3}\,uV .
\]

Dividing by \(V\) yields the useful identity  

\[
S = \frac{4}{3}\,\frac{U}{T}.
\tag{6}
\]

---

### Step 2 – Specific heat at constant volume  

Differentiate (6) at fixed \(V\):

\[
dS = \frac{4}{3}\!\left[\frac{dU}{T}-\frac{U}{T^{2}}\,dT\right].
\tag{7}
\]

On the other hand, at constant volume the reversible heat added is
\( \delta Q_{rev}=C_{V}\,dT\); hence  

\[
dS = \frac{C_{V}}{T}\,dT .
\tag{8}
\]

Equating (7) and (8) and noting that \(dU=C_{V}\,dT\) (because \(V\) is held
fixed) give  

\[
\frac{C_{V}}{T}= \frac{4}{3}\!
\left[\frac{C_{V}}{T}-\frac{U}{T^{2}}\right]\!.
\]

Multiplying by \(T\) and solving for \(C_{V}\),

\[
C_{V}=4\,\frac{U}{T}.
\tag{9}
\]

Since \(U = uV\),

\[
C_{V}=V\frac{du}{dT}=4\,\frac{uV}{T}
\;\Longrightarrow\;
\frac{du}{dT}=4\,\frac{u}{T}.
\tag{10}
\]

---

Equation (10) separates easily:

\[
\frac{du}{u}=4\,\frac{dT}{T}
\;\Longrightarrow\;
\ln u = 4\ln T + {\rm const},

so that  

\[
\boxed{\,u(T)=a\,T^{4}\,},
\tag{11}

\boxed{p=\tfrac13 u } .
\]

* \(J_{i}\) – **radiosity** (total outward radiant intensity) of plate \(i\),
* \(G_{i}\) – irradiation falling on plate \(i\).

For a diffuse grey surface whose surroundings consist only of the opposite plate,
the radiosity satisfies  

\[
J_{i}= \varepsilon _i E_{i}+ (1-\varepsilon _i)\,G_{i},
\qquad i=1,2 .
\tag{1}
\]

Because the plates are infinitely extended and face each other, the geometric
view factors are  

\[
F_{12}=F_{21}=1 ,
\]

so the irradiation received by either plate equals the radiosity of its neighbour,

\[
G_{1}=J_{2},\qquad 
G_{2}=J_{1}.                                            \tag{2}
\]

The net radiative heat flux from plate 1 to plate 2 (positive when directed
from hot toward cold) is therefore  

\[
W = J_{1}-J_{2}.                                          \tag{3}
\]

Insert Eq.(2) into Eq.(1):

\[
\begin{aligned}
J_{1}&=\varepsilon _1E_{1}+(1-\varepsilon _1)J_{2},\\[2mm]
J_{2}&=\varepsilon _2E_{2}+(1-\varepsilon _2)J_{1}.
\end{aligned}
\tag{4}
\]

Solving these simultaneous equations for the difference \(J_{1}-J_{2}\)
gives  

\[
J_{1}-J_{2}= \frac{\displaystyle \varepsilon _1\varepsilon _2\,(E_{1}-E_{2})}
                 {\displaystyle \varepsilon _1+\varepsilon _2-
                  \varepsilon _1\varepsilon _2 } .
\tag{5}
\]

Since the net transferred power per unit area is exactly the flux \(W\),

\[
\boxed{
      W=
      \frac{E_{1}-E_{2}}
           {\,\dfrac{E_{1}}{\varepsilon _1}+ \dfrac{E_{2}}{\varepsilon _2}-1 }
     }\;
\] 

which is the required relation (here \(\varepsilon _i=e_i\)).

\[
\dfrac{E_{1}}{1}+ \dfrac{E_{2}}{1}-1 = 1+1-1 =1 .
\]

questions: A compressor designed to compress air is used instead to compress helium. It is found that the compressor overheats. Explain this effect, assuming the compression is approximately adiabatic and the starting pressure is the same for both gases.
llm_answers:
analysisWe need to explain why using helium leads to overheating compared to air under similar conditions (same initial pressure). The key points:

- Helium has lower molecular weight, higher specific heat ratio γ = Cp/Cv ~1.66 vs air's ≈1.40.

- For adiabatic compression, temperature rise T2/T1 = (P2/P1)^{(γ−1)/γ}. Higher gamma gives larger exponent => greater temperature increase for given pressure ratio.

- Also helium has smaller molar mass leading to fewer molecules per unit volume? Actually density differences affect work done per kg; but main factor is γ.

- Additionally, thermal conductivity of He is high, but that may help dissipate heat not cause heating. However during rapid compression, limited time for conduction so internal energy rises more.

- Specific heats: Cv_He=3/2 R (~12.47 J/mol·K), Cp_He=5/2R (~20.79); for diatomic gas like N2/O2, Cv≈5/2R, Cp≈7/2R due to rotational degrees of freedom. So per mole, helium stores less internal energy change per degree K, meaning for same work input, temperature rise bigger because ΔU=nCvΔT -> ΔT = W/(nCv). Since Cv smaller, ΔT larger.

Thus explanation: With same pressure ratio, work required per mole is roughly P*V ln(P2/P1)? But actual mechanical work depends on PV^γ etc. In any case, helium experiences larger temperature rise causing overheating.

Also mention that helium being monatomic means no vibrational or rotational modes active at room temp, thus only translational DOF → lower heat capacity → larger temperature increase for same amount of work.

Provide equations: Adiabatic relation p V^γ = const, T V^(γ-1)=const, combine yields T2=T1*(p2/p1)^((γ-1)/γ).

Plug numbers: For typical compressor raising from 1 bar to say 10 bar, with γ_air=1.4 exponent=(0.4/1.4)=0.286, T_ratio~10^0.286≈1.93. If inlet 300K, outlet ~580K. For helium γ=1.67 exponent=0.402, T_ratio~10^0.402≈2.53, giving outlet ~760K. Much hotter.

Hence overheating.

Add note about cooling mechanisms: compressors often rely on oil/cooling water expecting certain temperature range; helium exceeds design limits.

For an adiabatic process  

\[

TV^{\gamma -1}= \text {constant},
\]

where  

\[
\gamma\equiv\frac{C_{p}}{C_{v}}
\]

is the ratio of the constant–pressure to the constant‑volume specific heats of the gas.   
Eliminating \(V\),

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}=
\left(\frac{p_{2}}{p_{1}}\right)^{\! (\gamma-1)/\gamma}
}\tag{1}
\]

### 1.   Values of \(\gamma\)

| Gas | Molecular nature | Degrees of freedom (room T) | \(C_v\) (J mol\(^{-1}\) K\(^{-1}\)) | \(C_p=C_v+R\) | \(\gamma=C_p/C_v\) |
|-----|------------------|----------------------------|-----------------------------------|--------------|--------------------|
| Air (mostly N₂,O₂) | Di‑atomic | 5 (3 trans + 2 rot.) | \(\tfrac52R\approx 20.8\) | \(\tfrac72R\approx 29.1\) | \(\approx 1.40\) |
| He    | Mono‑atomic      | 3 (translational only)     | \(\tfrac32R\approx 12.5\) | \(\tfrac52R\approx 20.8\) | \(\approx 1.67\) |

Helium’s \(\gamma\) is appreciably larger than that of air.

---

### 2.   Temperature rise for the same pressure ratio  

Take a realistic compression ratio for many industrial machines,
\(p_{2}/p_{1}=10\) (from 1 bar to 10 bar). Using Eq.(1):

*Air*

\[
\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}=10^{(\,1.40-1)/1.40}=10^{0.286}\simeq 1.93 .
\]

If the intake temperature is \(T_{1}=300\;\mathrm{K}\),

\[

*Helium*

\[
\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}=10^{(\,1.67-1)/1.67}=10^{0.402}\simeq 2.53 ,
\]

\[
T_{2}^{\rm (He)}\approx 2.53\times300\ {\rm K}\approx 760\ {\rm K}.
\]

The helium discharge temperature is therefore **about 30 % higher**, well above the design limit of most oil‑cooled compressors.

### 3.   Physical interpretation  

* **Higher \(\gamma\)** – Because helium possesses only three translational degrees of freedom it has a *smaller* constant‑volume heat capacity \(C_v\). When the piston does a given amount of work \(W\) on one mole,

\[
\Delta U=W=n C_v \,\Delta T\quad\Longrightarrow\quad 
\Delta T=\frac{W}{nC_v}.
\]

With a smaller \(C_v\), the same work produces a larger temperature increment.

* **Adiabatic law dependence** – Equation (1) shows directly that the temperature gain grows with \((\gamma-1)/\gamma\). A larger \(\gamma\) makes the exponent larger, hence a steeper rise of \(T\) for a fixed pressure boost.

questions: A steam turbine is operated with an intake temperature of 400$°C$, and an exhaust temperature of 150$°C$. What is the maximum amount of work the turbine can do for a given heat input $ Q $? Under what conditions is the maximum achieved?
llm_answers:
analysisWe need to interpret question: "maximum amount of work the turbine can do for a given heat input Q". This sounds like efficiency limit from Carnot cycle between temperatures T_hot = 400°C (673 K) and T_cold = 150°C (423 K). For a given heat input Q into turbine (i.e., heat added), max possible work W_max = η_Carnot * Q where η_Carnot = 1 - Tc/Th.

Thus compute:

T_h = 400 +273 = 673 K; T_c = 150+273=423 K.

η = 1 - 423/673 ≈ 1 - 0.6286 = 0.3714 ~37.14%.

So Wmax = 0.371*Q.

Maximum achieved when process is reversible i.e., turbine operates as part of a Carnot engine operating between those two reservoirs, no irreversibilities, frictionless, adiabatic expansion etc. Also assume that all heat addition occurs at Th and rejection at Tc, and turbine does work reversibly.

Answer includes condition: quasi-static, no entropy generation, ideal gas maybe but essentially reversible operation.

Provide steps: define second law ΔS_universe >=0 => Q/Th - Q_out/Tc ≥0 ; Work = Q_in - Q_out . Maximize work subject to equality gives Carnot.

Derive expression: W_max = Q*(1 - Tc/Th).

Hence final answer box.

Let's craft explanation.assistantfinalThe turbine receives a quantity of heat \(Q\) from a hot source at  

\[
T_{H}=400^{\circ}\text C = 400+273 = 673\;\text{K}
\]

and rejects heat to a cold sink at  

\[
T_{C}=150^{\circ}\text C = 150+273 = 423\;\text{K}.
\]

For any cyclic device the first‑law energy balance gives  

\[
W = Q_{\text{in}}-Q_{\text{out}},
\tag{1}
\]

where \(W\) is the net work produced per cycle.  
From the second law,

\[
\Delta S_{\text{univ}}
   =\frac{Q_{\text{in}}}{T_H}-\frac{Q_{\text{out}}}{T_C}\ge 0 .
\tag{2}
\]

To obtain **the largest possible work** we make the process **reversible**, i.e. set the inequality in Eq.(2) to an equality (\(\Delta S_{\text{univ}}=0\)). Solving (2) for \(Q_{\text{out}}\),

\[
\frac{Q_{\text{in}}}{T_H}= \frac{Q_{\text{out}}}{T_C}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad 
Q_{\text{out}} = Q_{\text{in}}\frac{T_C}{T_H}.
\]

Insert this result into the first‑law relation (1):

\[
W_{\max}= Q_{\text{in}}-
          Q_{\text{in}}\frac{T_C}{T_H}
        = Q_{\text{in}}\!\left(1-\frac{T_C}{T_H}\right).
\]

Therefore, for a specified heat input \(Q\equiv Q_{\text{in}}\)

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
      W_{\max}= Q\,\Bigl(1-\frac{T_C}{T_H}\Bigr)
            = Q\left(1-\frac{423\ {\rm K}}{673\ {\rm K}}\right)
            \approx 0.371\,Q }.
\]

---

### Conditions required for attaining the maximum

| Requirement | Physical meaning |
|-------------|-------------------|
| **Reversibility** | No internal irreversibilities (friction, turbulence, pressure drops); the expansion/compression processes are quasistatic. |
| **Heat transfer only at reservoir temperatures** | All heat is supplied while the working fluid is at \(T_H\) and rejected only when it reaches \(T_C\). |
| **No other sources or sinks of entropy** | The turbine plus its surroundings form a closed system whose total entropy change is zero. |

When these idealized conditions are met, the turbine functions as the high‑temperature leg of a **Carnot engine**, and the work output equals the Carnot efficiency multiplied by the heat input. Any deviation (finite‐rate heat transfer, friction, non‑ideal flow, mixing, etc.) introduces entropy production and reduces the actual work below this theoretical upper bound.

assistantfinalThe motion of a classical harmonic oscillator of mass \(m\) and spring constant \(k\) with total mechanical energy  

\[
E=\frac12 mv^{2}+ \frac12 kx^{2}
\]

is periodic with angular frequency  

\[
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}} .
\]

Because the “starting time’’ is totally unknown, the phase of the oscillation is taken to be **uniformly** distributed between \(0\) and \(2\pi\).  
Hence the probability of finding the particle at a certain coordinate is proportional to the fraction of a full cycle it spends there – i.e. inversely proportional to its instantaneous speed.

---

### 1.   Amplitude expressed through the energy  

At turning points (\(v=0\))

\[
E=\frac12 kA^{2}\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad 
A=\sqrt{\frac{2E}{k}}\;,
\]

so the trajectory may be written as  

\[
x(t)=A\cos(\omega t+\phi ),\qquad |\phi|\le 2\pi .
\]

---

### 2.   Speed as a function of position  

From conservation of energy,

\[
\frac12mv^{2}=E-\frac12 kx^{2},
\]
hence  

\[
|v(x)|=\sqrt{\frac{2}{m}\Bigl(E-\frac12 kx^{2}\Bigr)}
        =\omega\,\sqrt{A^{2}-x^{2}},\qquad |x|\le A .
\]

---

### 3.   Time spent in an infinitesimal interval  

During one complete period \(T=2\pi/\omega\),

\[
\text{time spent in }[x,x+dx]=\frac{2\,dx}{|v(x)|}.
\]

(The factor \(2\) accounts for the two passages—forward and backward—in each period.)

Therefore the probability density is  

\[
p(x)\,dx=
\frac{1}{T}\,\frac{2\,dx}{|v(x)|}
      =\frac{2}{T}\,\frac{dx}{\omega\sqrt{A^{2}-x^{2}}}
      =\frac{1}{\pi\sqrt{A^{2}-x^{2}}}\,dx ,
\quad |x|\le A .
\]

Outside the classically allowed region the particle never reaches, so \(p(x)=0\).

---

\[
\int_{-A}^{A}p(x)\,dx
    =\frac{1}{\pi}\int_{-A}^{A}\!\frac{dx}{\sqrt{A^{2}-x^{2}}}
    =\frac{1}{\pi}\big[\sin^{-1}(x/A)\big]_{-A}^{A}
    =\frac{1}{\pi}\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-(-\frac{\pi}{2})\right)=1 .
\]

Thus the expression is correctly normalised.

In classical statistical mechanics the *Boltzmann* definition reads  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
S_{\text{B}} = k_{B}\,\ln \Omega } ,
\]

where \(k_{B}\) is Boltzmann’s constant and \(\Omega\) is the number (or, more precisely, the measure) of microscopic states compatible with the given macroscopic constraints (energy, particle numbers, …).

For a system described by a probability distribution \(\{p_i\}\) over its quantum‑mechanical (or classical) microstates one uses the *Gibbs–Shannon* form  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
S_{\text{G}}=-k_{B}\sum_{i}p_{i}\ln p_{i}}
      \qquad (\hbox{continuous case : }
        S=-k_{B}\!\int d\Gamma\,\rho(\Gamma)\ln\rho(\Gamma)).
\]

Both expressions coincide when the distribution is uniform on the set of allowed microstates,
\(p_i=1/\Omega\), giving back \(S=k_{B}\ln\Omega\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

**(b)   Why the entropy of an isolated system either stays constant or grows**

Consider an isolated macroscopic system \(A\) whose Hilbert‐space (or phase‑space) dimension is fixed.  
Assume it can be split into two **weakly coupled** parts, \(B\) and \(C\),

\[
A=B+C ,\qquad H_{A}=H_{B}+H_{C}+V_{BC},
\]
with \(|V_{BC}| \ll |H_{B}|,|H_{C}|\); this guarantees:

* each sub‑system relaxes rapidly to its own internal equilibrium;
* the exchange of conserved quantities (energy, particles…) between them occurs on a much longer time scale.

---

### 1. Microscopic (fine‑grained) entropy – constancy

The exact density operator \(\hat\rho(t)\) evolves unitarily,

\[
\frac{{\rm d}}{{\rm d}t}\hat\rho(t)=-\frac{i}{\hbar}[H_{A},\hat\rho(t)] .
\]

Consequently the von Neumann entropy  

\[
S_{\!vN}(t)=-k_{B}\operatorname{Tr}\bigl[\hat\rho(t)\ln\hat\rho(t)\bigr]
\]

is invariant (`Liouville's theorem`). Thus **if one keeps track of all microscopic correlations**, the entropy never changes.

---

### 2. Coarse‑grained (thermodynamic) entropy – non‑decrease

Thermodynamics does **not** resolve those correlations. One replaces the true state by a product of equilibrium ensembles for the subsystems,

\[
\tilde\rho(t)=\rho_{B}^{\mathrm{eq}}\bigl[E_{B}(t)\bigr]\otimes
             \rho_{C}^{\mathrm{eq}}\bigl[E_{C}(t)\bigr],
\quad E_{B}+E_{C}=E_{\!tot}.
\]

The corresponding “macroscopic’’ entropy is  

\[
S_{\text{macro}}(t)
    =k_{B}\Bigl[\ln\Omega_{B}\bigl(E_{B}(t)\bigr)+
                \ln\Omega_{C}\bigl(E_{C}(t)\bigr)\Bigr].
\tag{1}
\]

Because the subsystems are weakly coupled, their individual microcanonical densities change only through the slow transfer of energy (and/or particles). The total number of accessible microstates of the whole isolated system is

\[
\Omega_{A}(E_{\!tot})=
     \sum_{E_{B}} \Omega_{B}(E_{B})\;\Omega_{C}(E_{\!tot}-E_{B}),
\]

so that the **equilibrium value** of the entropy is obtained by maximizing the right‑hand side with respect to the partition of the conserved quantity. Using Stirling’s approximation for large systems,

\[
\max_{E_{B}}\bigl[S_{B}(E_{B})+S_{C}(E_{\!tot}-E_{B})\bigr] .
\]

The maximum is reached when  

\[
\left.\frac{\partial S_{B}}{\partial E_{B}}\right|
       _{E^{*}_{B}}
   =
\left.\frac{\partial S_{C}}{\partial E_{C}}\right|
       _{E^{*}_{C}},
\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad T_{B}=T_{C},
\]

the usual thermal‑equilibrium condition.

If initially the subsystems have different temperatures (or chemical potentials), there exists a direction of spontaneous energy flow that **increases** the summed logarithm (1). Explicitly, let a small amount \(\delta Q\) move from \(B\) to \(C\):

\[
\Delta S = \frac{\delta Q}{T_{C}}-\frac{\delta Q}{T_{B}}>0
          \quad\text{when }T_{B}>T_{C}.
\]

Thus while the microscopic entropy stays unchanged, the **coarse‑grained entropy rises monotonically** until the equality of intensive parameters is fulfilled. At that point the macroscopic description becomes stationary and any subsequent microscopic rearrangements merely shuffle hidden correlations, leaving the observable entropy **constant**.

---

### 3. Summary of the conditions

| Situation                               | Behaviour of the observed entropy |
|----------------------------------------|-----------------------------------|
| System truly isolated, **already** in global equilibrium (same \(T,\mu,…\) throughout) | Remains constant. |
| Isolated but composed of subsystems with differing intensive variables (e.g. \(T_{B}\neq T_{C}\)) | Increases monotonically until equilibrium is reached; thereafter stays constant. |
| Weak coupling + rapid intra‑subsystem equilibration ⇒ well defined separate entropies. |
| Ergodic / mixing dynamics ensure that the reachable region of phase space corresponds to the maximal \(\Omega_{A}\). |

Hence, for an isolated macroscopic body the **second law of thermodynamics** emerges naturally: the thermodynamic (coarse‑grained) entropy cannot decrease; it stays flat only once the system has relaxed to its unique equilibrium macrostate.

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Entropy definition: }\; S=k_{B}\ln\Omega
                              =-k_{B}\sum_{i}p_{i}\ln p_{i}.\\[4pt]
&\text{Isolated system:}\\
&\qquad\text{If }B,C\text{ already share the same }T,\mu,\dots\Rightarrow S=\text{const}.\\
&\qquad\text{Otherwise }S\text{ increases until }T_{B}=T_{C}\;( {\rm equilibrium}),\text{ then }S\text{ stops growing.}
\end{aligned}}
\]

Now produce final answer.assistantfinalThe entropy balance for a continuous body can be written locally as  

\[
\rho\,\dot s=-\nabla\!\cdot {\bf J}_s+\sigma ,
\qquad\sigma\ge 0,
\]

where  

* \(\rho\) – mass density,  
* \(s\) – specific entropy,   
* \({\bf J}_s\) – entropy‑flux vector,  
* \(\sigma\) – **local rate of entropy generation** per unit volume (the quantity we seek).

---

### 1. Entropy flux for pure heat conduction  

Heat conducted through the material produces an entropy flux equal to the heat‐flux divided by the absolute temperature,

\[
{\bf J}_s=\frac{{\bf q}}{T},
\]

with \({\bf q}\) the conductive heat–flux vector.

Fourier’s law gives this heat‑flux:

\[
{\bf q}= -k\nabla T ,                     \tag{1}
\]
\(k\;(>0)\) being the (isotropic) thermal conductivity.

---

### 2. Substituting into the entropy balance  

Insert \({\bf J}_s={\bf q}/T\) :

\[
-\nabla\!\cdot{\bf J}_s=
-\nabla\!\cdot\left(\frac{{\bf q}}{T}\right)
      =-\frac{1}{T}\,\underbrace{\nabla\!\cdot{\bf q}}_{\text{energy source}}
        -{\bf q}\!\cdot\nabla\!\Bigl(\frac{1}{T}\Bigr).
\]

Using the first law of thermo­dynamics one may replace 
\((1/T)(\nabla\!\cdot{\bf q})\) by terms that involve mechanical work or internal heating;
these do not contribute to irreversibility caused solely by conduction.
Hence the **irreversible part** of the entropy change comes only from the second term:

\[
\sigma = {\bf q}\!\cdot\nabla\!\Bigl(\frac{1}{T}\Bigr).\tag{2}
\]

Equation (2) is the general expression for entropy generation associated with heat transport.

---

### 3. Express \(\sigma\) in terms of the temperature field  

From calculus  

\[
\nabla\!\Bigl(\frac{1}{T}\Bigr)= -\frac{\nabla T}{T^{2}},
\]

so that, employing Fourier’s law (1),

\[
\sigma = {\bf q}\!\cdot\biggl[-\frac{\nabla T}{T^{2}}\biggr]
       =\bigl(-k\nabla T\bigr)\!\cdot\biggl[-\frac{\nabla T}{T^{2}}\biggr].
\]

Because the dot product of a vector with itself yields its squared magnitude,

\[
\boxed{\;\displaystyle 
\sigma = \frac{k}{T^{2}}\;|\nabla T|^{2}\;}
\]

or, writing explicitly with components,

\[
\sigma = \frac{k}{T^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{3}\left(\frac{\partial T}{\partial x_i}\right)^{2}.
\]

---

## Result  

The **local rate of entropy generation per unit volume** in a solid that conducts heat according to Fourier’s law is  

\[
\boxed{
\dot{s}_{\mathrm{gen}} = \frac{k}{T^{2}}\,\bigl|\nabla T\bigr|^{2}
 } .
\]

Its dimensions are  

\[
[\dot{s}_{\mathrm{gen}}]=\frac{\text{W}}{\text{m}^{3}\,\text{K}}
    =\frac{\text{J}}{\text{s}\,\text{m}^{3}\,\text{K}},
\]

which indeed corresponds to “joules of entropy produced per cubic metre per second”.

Equation (1) is linear; its formal solution is

\[
v(t)=v(0)e^{-\gamma t}+ \frac{1}{m}\int_{0}^{t}e^{-\gamma (t-s)}\;\xi(s)\,ds ,
\qquad \gamma\equiv\frac{\lambda}{m}.
\tag{3}
\]

Multiplying two copies of (3) and averaging over the noise, using (2),

\[
\begin{aligned}
C_v(t)&\equiv\langle v(t)v(0)\rangle\\[2mm]
&=
\Big\langle v(0)^2\Big\rangle e^{-\gamma t}
      +\frac{1}{m^2}\!\int_{0}^{t}\! ds\,e^{-\gamma (t-s)}
        \big\langle \xi(s)v(0)\big\rangle .
\end{aligned}
\]

Because \(\xi\) is uncorrelated with the initial velocity, the second term vanishes.
In equilibrium the equipartition theorem gives  
\(\displaystyle \big\langle v(0)^2\big\rangle =\frac{T}{m}\); therefore

\[
\boxed{C_v(t)=\frac{T}{m}\,e^{-\gamma t}}\,.     \tag{4}
\]

\[
\Delta x(t)=x(t)-x(0)=\int_{0}^{t}v(s)\,ds .

\qquad (\beta\equiv 1/k_{B}T)
\]

so that the Boltzmann factor of a single moment is  

\[
z_{1}=e^{-\beta(-\mu _0B)}+e^{-\beta(\mu _0B)}
      =e^{\beta\mu _0B}+e^{-\beta\mu _0B}
      =2\cosh (\beta\mu _0B).
\]

Because the \(N\) moments do not interact,
the total canonical partition function is simply the product of the
single‑particle ones:

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
Z(N,B,T)=\bigl[\,2\cosh (\beta\mu _0B)\,\bigr]^{N}}
\tag{a}
\]

### Internal energy and specific heat  

The Helmholtz free energy \(F=-k_BT\ln Z\) yields the mean energy  

\[
U=-\frac{\partial}{\partial\beta}\ln Z
   =-N\;\frac{\sinh(\beta\mu_0B)}{\cosh(\beta\mu_0B)}\;
     \mu_0B
   =-N\mu_0B\tanh\!\left(\frac{\mu_0B}{k_BT}\right).
\]

Define  

\[
y\equiv\frac{\mu_0B}{k_BT}.
\]

Then  

\[
U=-N\mu_0B\tanh y .
\]

At constant field the specific heat is  

\[
C=\Bigl(\frac{\partial U}{\partial T}\Bigr)_B
   =N k_B\,y^{2}\operatorname{sech}^{2}y
   =N k_B\left(\frac{\mu_0B}{k_BT}\right)^{2}
        \operatorname{sech}^{2}\!
          \left(\frac{\mu_0B}{k_BT}\right).
\]

Hence  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
C(N,B,T)=Nk_{B}\left(\frac{\mu_{0}B}{k_{B}T}\right)^{2}
         {\rm sech}^{2}\!\left(\frac{\mu_{0}B}{k_{B}T}\right)}
\tag{b}
\]

### Thermal average magnetic moment  

For one moment  

\[
\langle\mu\rangle=
\mu_{0}\frac{e^{\beta\mu_0B}-e^{-\beta\mu_0B}}%
                {e^{\beta\mu_0B}+e^{-\beta\mu_0B}}
            =\mu_{0}\tanh(\beta\mu_0B),
\]

and therefore for the whole sample  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\overline{M}(N,B,T)=N\mu_{0}\tanh\!\left(
                     \frac{\mu_{0}B}{k_{B}T}\right)}
\tag{c}
\]

### Susceptibility and Curie’s law  

The (isothermal) magnetic susceptibility is  

\[
\chi=\left.\frac{\partial\overline{M}}{\partial B}\right|_{T}
    =N\mu_{0}\,\frac{{\rm d}}{{\rm d}B}
       \tanh(\beta\mu_{0}B)
    =N\mu_{0}^{2}\beta\,
      {\rm sech}^{2}(\beta\mu_{0}B)
    =\frac{N\mu_{0}^{2}}{k_{B}T}\,
      {\rm sech}^{2}\!\left(\frac{\mu_{0}B}{k_{B}T}\right).
\]

In the **high–temperature** limit \((\mu_{0}B\ll k_{B}T)\),

\[
\tanh y\simeq y,\qquad {\rm sech}^{2}y\simeq 1,
\]
so that  

\[
\overline{M}\approx N\mu_{0}\frac{\mu_{0}B}{k_{B}T},
\qquad
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\chi\approx\frac{N\mu_{0}^{2}}{k_{B}}\frac{1}{T}},
\]

which is precisely Curie’s law \(\chi\propto 1/T\).

Initially the crystal is in contact with a bath at  

\[
T_i = 1\ {\rm K},\qquad    
B_i = 10\,000\ {\rm G}=1\ {\rm T}.

It is then insulated (no heat exchange) and the field is slowly lowered to  

\[

\]

\[
S(T_i,B_i)=S(T_f,B_f).
\]

\[
N k_{\!B}\Bigl[\ln\!\bigl(2\cosh x_i\bigr)-x_i\tanh x_i\Bigr]
=
N k_{\!B}\Bigl[\ln\!\bigl(2\cosh x_f\bigr)-x_f\tanh x_f\Bigr],
\]

\[

\quad\Longrightarrow\quad

       =1\ {\rm K}\times\frac{10^{2}}{10^{4}}
       =0.01\ {\rm K}.

demagnetisation*: the work performed by lowering the magnetic field

             \mathrm{sech}\!\Bigl(
              \frac{\mu _0 B_f}{k_{\!B}T_f}\Bigr)
           \ll \Delta M_i .
\]

Thus, after the isolated field‐reduction the crystal becomes much cooler
while retaining virtually full magnetic ordering—a textbook example of
magnetic‑refrigeration.

\[
\boxed{\text{Final temperature }\;T_f\sim 10^{-2}\ {\rm K}
\;(adiabatic\ demagnetisation).\;}
\]

The river at temperature \(T_{0}\) acts as the cold reservoir of an **ideal (Carnot)** heat pump.

\frac{T}{\,T-T_{0}\,},
\qquad (\text{ideal pump})
\]

* \({\cal Q}_h\) – useful heat delivered to the building.

\[

\frac{T}{T-T_{0}}\;W .
\tag{1}
\]

At the same time the building loses heat to the river according to Newton’s law  

\[
\dot Q_{\rm loss}= \alpha\,(T-T_{0}),
\tag{2}
\]

\[
{\cal Q}_h-\dot Q_{\rm loss}=0 .
\tag{3}
\]

### (a)   Determination of the equilibrium temperature \(T_{e}\)

Insert (1)–(2) into (3):

\[
\frac{T}{T-T_{0}}\,W = \alpha\,(T-T_{0}) .
\]

Introduce the temperature excess  

\[
\Delta \equiv T-T_{0}>0 ,
\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad T=T_{0}+ \Delta .
\]

\[

This quadratic equation for \(\Delta\) reads  

\[
\boxed{\;\alpha \Delta ^2-W\Delta-WT_{0}=0\;}
\]

\[
\Delta =
\frac{W+\sqrt{W^{2}+4\alpha WT_{0}}}{2\alpha }
      =\frac{W}{2\alpha }\Bigl[1+
        \sqrt{1+\frac{4\alpha T_{0}}{W}}\Bigr] .
\]

\[
\boxed{
T_{e}=T_{0}+\Delta
     =T_{0}+ \frac{W}{2\alpha }
       \biggl[1+\Bigl(1+\frac{4\alpha T_{0}}{W}\Bigr)^{1/2}\biggr]}

\[

A necessary condition for a negative temperature is that the **energy spectrum be bounded from above**, so that adding energy eventually reduces the number of available micro‑states (entropy falls with further increase of \(E\)).

     T\!\left(\frac{\partial S}{\partial V}\right)_{T}-p\\[2mm]

Consider a mono‑atomic **ideal gas** of \(N\) indistinguishable particles of mass \(m\) confined in a volume \(V\) at temperature \(T\).
The single–particle energies are  

\[
\varepsilon_{\mathbf p}= \frac{{p}^{2}}{2m},
\qquad 
{\bf p}\in {\mathbb R}^{3}.
\]

---

### 1. One‑particle partition function  

In the canonical ensemble the translational part of the one‑particle partition function is  

\[
Q_{1}(T,V)=\frac{1}{h^{3}}\int d^{3}r\,d^{3}p\;
   e^{-\beta p^{2}/2m}
      =\frac{V}{h^{3}}
        \Bigl[\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }
               dp_x\,e^{-\beta p_x^{2}/2m}\Bigr]^{3}.
\]

Each Gaussian integral evaluates to  
\(
\sqrt{2\pi m/\beta}= \sqrt{2\pi m k_{B}T},
\)
so  

\[
Q_{1}(T,V)=\frac{V}{h^{3}}\,
          (2\pi m k_{B}T )^{3/2}
         =\frac{V}{\Lambda ^{3}},
\]
where  

\[
\boxed{\;\Lambda\equiv\frac{h}{\sqrt{2\pi m k_{B}T}}\;}
\]

is the **thermal de Broglie wavelength**, and \(\Lambda^{3}=V_{Q}\).

Hence  

\[
q_{1}\equiv\frac{Q_{1}}{V}= \frac{1}{\Lambda^{3}}
    =\frac{1}{V_{Q}} .
\tag{1}
\]

---

### 2. Grand‑canonical description – fugacity  

Introduce the fugacity  

\[
z\equiv e^{\beta\mu}=e^{\mu/k_{B}T}\equiv\lambda ,
\]

and write the grand‑partition function for non‑interacting particles,

\[
\Xi(z,T,V)=\prod_{\mathbf p}
           \bigl[1-z\,e^{-\beta\varepsilon_{\mathbf p}}\bigr]^{-1}.
\]

When the gas is dilute (\(\lambda\ll 1\)), we may expand the logarithm:

\[
\ln\Xi=
     \sum_{\mathbf p}\! \bigl[z\,e^{-\beta\varepsilon_{\mathbf p}}+O(z^{2})\bigr]
   =z\,Q_{1}+ O(z^{2}),
\]

because each term of order \(z^{n}\;(n\ge 2)\) corresponds to Bose/Fermi
statistics and is negligible in the Boltzmann regime.

The mean particle number follows from  

\[
\langle N\rangle =z\frac{\partial\ln\Xi}{\partial z}
                =z\,Q_{1}+O(z^{2})
                \approx z\,Q_{1}.
\]

Dividing by the volume gives the number density  

\[
n=\frac{\langle N\rangle}{V}\approx
   z\,\frac{Q_{1}}{V}=z\,q_{1}.
\]

Using Eq.(1),

\[
n=z\,\frac{1}{\Lambda^{3}}
   \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
   z=n\,\Lambda^{3}=n\,V_{Q}.
\]

Since \(z=e^{\mu/k_{B}T}\equiv\lambda\),

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
       \lambda = e^{\mu/k_{B}T}= n\,V_{Q}},\qquad 
       \text{valid for }\lambda\ll 1 .
\]

---

From the Sackur–Tetrode entropy of an ideal monatomic gas  

\[
\frac{S}{Nk_{B}}=
   \ln\!\Bigl[\frac{V}{N}
            \Bigl(\frac{4\pi mU}{3Nh^{2}}\Bigr)^{3/2}\Bigr]+
   \tfrac52,
\]

the Helmholtz free energy \(F=U-TS\) yields  

\[
\mu =\Bigl(\frac{\partial F}{\partial N}\Bigr)_{TV}

\]

\[

\]

Both routes lead to the same relation.

\[

\lambda \;=\; e^{\mu/k_{B}T}\;=\; n\,V_{Q},
\qquad

* \(\bar v\equiv\sqrt{\langle v^{2}\rangle }\) – mean molecular speed,
* \(\lambda\) – mean free path,
* \(\rho=n m\) – mass density.

\]

\[

\tag{4}
\]

\[

\frac{P}{\eta}= \nu_{\text{coll}}
}

\tag{2}
\]

\[

      =n_{1}\frac{R}{\gamma_1-1}+n_{2}\frac{R}{\gamma_2-1}.
\tag{3}
\]

pressure,

\[
p=\frac{(n_{1}+n_{2})RT}{V}= \frac{NVRT}{V},
\qquad N=n_{1}+n_{2}=0.30~{\rm mol}.     
\tag{4}
\]

\[
C_{V}^{\mathrm{tot}}\;dT+\frac{NRT}{V}\,dV=0 .
\tag{5}
\]

Dividing by \(T\) :

\[
C_{V}^{\mathrm{tot}}\frac{dT}{T}+NR\frac{dV}{V}=0 .
\tag{6}
\]

Integration gives  

\[
T\,V^{\displaystyle\frac{NR}{C_{V}^{\mathrm{tot}}}}={\rm const}.
\tag{7}
\]

Introduce the **mean molar heat capacities**

\[
\bar C_{V}= \frac{C_{V}^{\mathrm{tot}}}{N},\qquad       
\bar C_{P}= \frac{C_{P}^{\mathrm{tot}}}{N},
\]

with \(C_{P}^{\mathrm{tot}}=n_{1}C_{P1}+n_{2}C_{P2}\).
Because \(C_{Pi}-C_{Vi}=R\) for any ideal gas,   

\[
\boxed{\;
\gamma_{\rm eff}= \frac{\bar C_{P}}{\bar C_{V}}
               =1+\frac{R}{\bar C_{V}}
               =1+\frac{NR}{C_{V}^{\mathrm{tot}}}\;}
\tag{8}
\]

and Eq.(7) takes exactly the form obtained for a single gas,

\[
\boxed{ \; T\,V^{\gamma_{\rm eff}-1}= {\rm const}},\qquad
\boxed{ \; p\,V^{\gamma_{\rm eff}}    = {\rm const}} .
\tag{9}
\]

assistantfinal**(a)   Isothermal reversible expansion**

For one mole of an ideal gas kept at a fixed absolute temperature  

\[
T = 0^{\circ}{\rm C}=273.15\ {\rm K},
\]

the work performed during a reversible isothermal change from \(V_{i}=V_{0}\) to  
\(V_{f}=10\,V_{0}\) is  

\[
W=\int_{V_i}^{V_f}P\,dV=nRT\!\int_{V_i}^{V_f}\frac{dV}{V}
      =nRT\;\ln\!\left(\frac{V_f}{V_i}\right).
\]

With \(n=1\) mol and \(R=8.314\ {\rm J\,mol^{-1}K^{-1}}\),

\[
\begin{aligned}
W &= (1)(8.314\ {\rm J\,mol^{-1}K^{-1}})(273.15\ {\rm K})
        \,\ln(10)\\[2mm]
  &\approx 2.271\times10^{3}\ {\rm J}\times 2.302585 \\[2mm]
  &\boxed{\displaystyle W\simeq 5.2\times10^{3}\ {\rm J}}
\end{aligned}
\]

---

**(b)   Reversible adiabatic expansion**

In a reversible adiabatic process for an ideal gas,

\[
TV^{\gamma-1}= \text{constant},\qquad 
\gamma\equiv\frac{C_p}{C_v}.
\]

Hence, with the same initial conditions (\(T_i=273.15\ {\rm K},\;
V_i=V_0\)) and a final volume \(V_f=10V_0\),

\[
T_f=T_i\Bigl(\frac{V_i}{V_f}\Bigr)^{\gamma-1}
     =273.15\;(10^{-1})^{\gamma-1}
     =273.14\;10^{-(\gamma-1)} .
\]

Converting back to degrees Celsius (\(t_f=T_f-273.15\))

\[
\boxed{\,t_f = 273.15\bigl[10^{-(\gamma-1)}-1\bigr]\ ^\circ{\rm C}\, } .
\]

---

---

### 1. First‑law expressions for the two processes  

For a homogeneous solid the first law reads  

\[
dU=\delta Q-p\,dV ,
\tag{1}
\]

where \(p\) is the externally applied hydrostatic pressure (the work is taken **by** the system).
If the temperature is raised while keeping the **volume fixed**, eq.(1) gives  

\[
\boxed{\;\delta Q_{V}=dU\;}
\tag{2}
\]

because \(dV=0\).

When the temperature is raised at **constant pressure**, the volume does change;
eq.(1) becomes  

\[
\boxed{\;\delta Q_{p}=dU+p\,dV\;}
\tag{3}
\]

(the extra term accounts for the mechanical work performed against the surrounding pressure).

Subtracting (2) from (3),

\[
\delta Q_{p}-\delta Q_{V}=p\,dV .
\tag{4}
\]

Dividing (4) by \(dT\) defines the difference of the heat capacities,

\[
C_{p}-C_{V}=p\left(\frac{\partial V}{\partial T}\right)_{p}.      \tag{5}
\]

Equation (5) is exact provided the internal energy of a solid depends essentially only on its temperature – a very good approximation for most crystalline solids.

---

### 2. Relating \((\partial V/\partial T)_{p}\) to the linear expansion coefficient  

Let the solid have total mass \(M\) and (average) density \(\rho\); its equilibrium volume is  

\[
V=\frac{M}{\rho } .
\tag{6}
\]

For an isotropic solid the linear coefficient of thermal expansion \(\alpha\) is defined by  

\[
\frac{dl}{l}= \alpha\, dT .
\]

Since each dimension expands by the factor \((1+\alpha dT)\), the relative change of the volume is three times larger:

\[
\frac{dV}{V}=3\alpha\, dT\quad\Longrightarrow\quad  
\left(\frac{\partial V}{\partial T}\right)_{p}=3\alpha V .
\tag{7}
\]

Using (6) in (7),

\[
\left(\frac{\partial V}{\partial T}\right)_{p}=3\alpha\frac{M}{\rho }.    \tag{8}
\]

Insert Eq.(8) into Eq.(5):

\[
C_{p}-C_{V}=p\Big(3\alpha\frac{M}{\rho }\Big)
          =\frac{3\alpha M p}{\rho } .
\]

\[
\boxed{\,C_{p}-C_{V}= \displaystyle \frac{3\alpha M p}{\rho }\, } .
\]

C_{p}-C_{V}= \frac{3\alpha M p}{\rho }

on a \(p\!-\!V\) chart.  
From \(V=10\) L to \(V=1\) L the pressure rises tenfold:
\(P_{B}=10P_{0}\).

**Adiabetic branch \(BC\)**  

Reversible adiabats satisfy  

\[
P\,V^{\gamma}=K,\qquad 
K=P_{B}V_{B}^{\gamma}=10P_{0}\;(1)^{\gamma}=10P_{0}.
\]

When the volume again reaches \(10\) L,

\[
P_{C}= \frac{K}{V^{\gamma}}
      =\frac{10P_{0}}{10^{\gamma}}
      =10^{\,1-\gamma }P_{0}
      =10^{-2/3}P_{0}\approx0.215\,P_{0}.
\]

The adiabat therefore lies **steeper** than the isotherm (slope \(-\gamma\))
and meets the vertical axis at a much lower pressure.

---

### (b)  Di‑atomic gas (\(\gamma\simeq\frac74=1.40\))

Exactly the same construction, now with \(\gamma=1.40\):

\[
P_{C}=10^{\,1-\gamma }P_{0}=10^{-0.4}P_{0}\approx0.398\,P_{0},
\]

so the adiabat ends at a higher pressure than for the mon‑atomic case,
but still well below the original atmospheric pressure.  
Its curvature is between those of the two isotherms.

Both diagrams look schematically like this  

```
          ^    p
          |
   iso    |        .
   (γ=1)  |     .       .
          |  .             .
          |____________________> V
                1         10
               AB (iso.) BC (adiab.)
``` 

(the dashed curve is the adiabat; the solid curve is the isotherm.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (c)  Net work over the whole cycle

Take “work done **by** the system” as positive.

*Isothermal compression*  

\[
W_{\mathrm{iso}}=
\int_{V_A}^{V_B}P\,{\rm d}V
=nRT\!\int_{10}^{1}\frac{{\rm d}V}{V}
=nRT\ln\!\left(\frac{1}{10}\right)
=-\,nRT\ln10 .
\tag{2}
\]

Using (1), \(nRT=P_{0}V_{A}=10P_{0}\),

\[
W_{\mathrm{iso}}=-10P_{0}\ln10\;<0 .
\]

*Adiabatic expansion*  

For a reversible adiabat  

\[
W_{\mathrm{adia}}=
\frac{P_{B}V_{B}-P_{C}V_{C}}{\gamma-1}
=\frac{10P_{0}-10^{\,2-\gamma}P_{0}}{\gamma-1}>0 .
\tag{3}
\]

Adding (2) and (3),

\[
W_{\text{net}}=
-P_{0}\Bigl[10\ln10-
\frac{10-10^{\,2-\gamma}}{\gamma-1}\Bigr].
\]

Evaluating the bracket :

| Gas            | \(\gamma\) | Bracket value | Sign of \(W_{\text{net}}\) |
|----------------|------------|---------------|---------------------------|
| Mono‑atomic    | \(5/3\)    | \(\displaystyle 10\ln10-\frac{10-10^{1/3}}{2/3}=11.26\) | **Negative** |
| Di‑atomic      | \(7/5\)    | \(\displaystyle 10\ln10-\frac{10-10^{0.6}}{0.4}=7.98\)   | **Negative** |

Thus **the net work is negative**, i.e. **more work is done on the gas than
by it**.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (d)  Comparison between gases

The magnitude \(|W_{\text{net}}|\) is

\[
|W_{\text{mono}}|\;>\;|W_{\text{diatom}},
\]

so the **net work done on the system is smaller for the di‑atomic gas**
than for the mono‑atomic one.  
(The larger \(\gamma\) of the mono‑atomic gas makes its adiabat steeper,
producing a larger positive adiabatic work which reduces—but does not
overcome—the negative isothermal contribution.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Net work }W_{\text{net}}<0\quad\Longrightarrow\text{work done on the gas}\\[2mm]
&|W_{\text{net}}|_{\text{monatomic}}>|W_{\text{net}}|_{\text{diatomic}}
\end{aligned}}
\]

assistantfinalThe inner sphere (\(r\)) and the concentric thin shell (\(R\)) are perfect black‑bodies.  
Only radiative heat transfer occurs (the inter­stitial region is evacuated).

### 1.   Heat–transfer “resistances”

For two black surfaces exchanging radiation the **thermal resistance** associated with the
exchange is  

\[
R_{\text {rad}}=\frac{1}{A\,\sigma},
\qquad 
G_{\text {rad}}=\frac{1}{R_{\text {rad}}}=A\sigma ,
\]

where \(A\) is the appropriate geometrical area and \(\sigma\) is the Stefan–Boltzmann constant.

Because the inner sphere completely views the inner wall of the outer shell,
the view factor \(F_{12}=1\); therefore the radiative conductance between the two
surfaces is   

\[
G_{12}=4\pi r^{2}\,\sigma .
\]

Similarly, the outer shell radiates to deep space (taken at \(T=0\)); the
conductance for this leg is  

\[
G_{23}=4\pi R^{2}\,\sigma .
\]

Since the shell is thin, the two legs act **in series**, hence their
resistances add:

\[
R_{\rm tot}= \frac{1}{G_{12}}+\frac{1}{G_{23}}
          =\frac{1}{4\pi\sigma}
            \left(\frac{1}{r^{2}}+\frac{1}{R^{2}}\right).
\]

Consequently the overall radiative conductance from the hot sphere to space is  

\[
G_{\rm eff}= \frac{1}{R_{\rm tot}}
           =\frac{4\pi\sigma }{\displaystyle\frac{1}{r^{2}}+
                                 \frac{1}{R^{2}} }
           =4\pi\sigma\;
             \frac{r^{2}R^{2}}{R^{2}+r^{2}} .
\]

---

### 2.   Cooling powers

*Without* any shield the sphere alone loses power  

\[
\dot Q_{\;\text{free}}=
4\pi r^{2}\,\sigma T^{4}.
\]

*With* the shield the net power transferred to space is  

\[
\dot Q_{\;\text{shaded}}=
G_{\rm ef}\,T^{4}
      =4\pi\sigma\,
        \frac{r^{2}R^{2}}{R^{2}+r^{2}}\,T^{4}.
\]

---

### 3.   Reduction factor

The factor by which the presence of the shield diminishes the cooling rate is

\[
f=\frac{\dot Q_{\;\text{shaded}}}{\dot Q_{\;\text{free}}}
  =\frac{ \dfrac{r^{2}R^{2}}{R^{2}+r^{2}} }{ r^{2}}
  =\boxed{\frac{R^{2}}{R^{2}+r^{2}} } .
\]

This has precisely the required algebraic form  

\[
f=\frac{aR^{2}}{R^{2}+b r^{2}},
\]

so that  

\[
\boxed{a=1},\qquad\boxed{b=1}.
\]

--- 

Therefore the radiation shield lowers the cooling rate of the inner black
sphere by the factor  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle\frac{R^{2}}{R^{2}+r^{2}} } .
\]

\[
u(T,V)=c\,T-\frac{a}{V},
\qquad   (\text{$c$ – constant})
\]

and the fluid satisfies the van der Waals equation  

\[
\Bigl(P+\frac{a}{V^{2}}\Bigr)(V-b)=RT .
\tag{1}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Heat capacity at constant volume  

By definition  

\[
C_{V}= \left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial T}\right) _{V}.
\]

Because the only \(T\)-dependence of \(u\) is linear,

\[
\boxed{C_{V}=c } .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Heat capacity at constant pressure  

The molar enthalpy is  

\[
h=u+PV =cT-\frac{a}{V}+PV .
\]

Hence  

\[
C_{P}= \left(\frac{\partial h}{\partial T}\right) _{P}
      =c+\Bigl(P+\frac{a}{V^{2}}\Bigr)
        \left(\frac{\partial V}{\partial T}\right) _{P}.
\tag{2}
\]

To obtain \((\partial V/\partial T)_{P}\) we differentiate Eq.(1) at
fixed \(P\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{\partial}{\partial T}\!\Big[(P+\frac{a}{V^{2}})
          (V-b)-RT\Big]=0\\[2mm]
&\Longrightarrow 
\Big[-\frac{2a}{V^{3}}(V-b)+(P+\frac{a}{V^{2}})\Big]\,
       \Big(\frac{\partial V}{\partial T}\Big)_{P}=R .
\end{aligned}
\]

Using the product rule the bracket simplifies to  

\[
\frac{P V^{3}-aV+2ab}{V^{3}},
\]

so that  

\[
\boxed{
\left(\frac{\partial V}{\partial T}\right)_{P}
     =\frac{RV^{3}}
            {P V^{3}-aV+2ab}} .
\tag{3}
\]

Insert (3) into (2):

\[
\begin{aligned}
C_{P}&=
c+(P+\frac{a}{V^{2}})\;
    \frac{RV^{3}}{P V^{3}-aV+2ab}\\[2mm]
 &=c+
   \frac{R\,(P V^{3}+aV)}
        {P V^{3}-aV+2ab}.
\end{aligned}
\]

It is convenient to eliminate the combination \(P V^{3}\) with the
equation of state (1):
\[
P=\frac{RT}{V-b}-\frac{a}{V^{2}}
\;\Longrightarrow\;
P V^{3}= \frac{RT\,V^{3}}{V-b}-aV .
\]

With this replacement the result can be written solely in terms of
\(T,\;V\) (or, after solving (1), in terms of \(T\) and \(P\)).  
A compact form is therefore  

\[
\boxed{
C_{P}=c+
\frac{R\bigl(P V^{3}+aV\bigr)}
     {P V^{3}-aV+2ab}},\qquad 
\text{where }V\text{ satisfies }(1).
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
**Result**

\[
\boxed{C_{V}=c},\qquad   
\boxed{C_{P}=c+\displaystyle\frac{R\bigl(P V^{3}+aV\bigr)}
                                   {P V^{3}-aV+2ab}},
\quad\text{with }(P+\frac{a}{V^{2}})(V-b)=RT .
\]

assistantfinal**(a)   Radiative‐equilibrium estimate of the Sun’s surface temperature**

The Sun radiates approximately as a black‑body of temperature \(T_{S}\).
Its total radiant power is  

\[
P_{\odot}= \sigma T_{S}^{4}\;(4\pi R_{\odot}^{2}) .
\]

At the orbital distance of the Earth (\(d\simeq 1\,\text{AU}\)) this power is spread uniformly over a sphere of area  
\(4\pi d^{2}\); therefore the **solar flux** (power per unit area normal to the rays) at the top of the Earth’s atmosphere is  

\[
F_\odot=\frac{P_{\odot}}{4\pi d^{2}}
        =\sigma T_{S}^{4}\,\frac{R_{\odot}^{2}}{d^{2}}\; .
\tag{1}
\]

Because the Sun subtends a small angle \(\theta\) (full angular diameter) as viewed from the Earth,

\[
\sin\!\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)\simeq\frac{R_{\odot}}{d},
\qquad 
\Rightarrow\quad 
\frac{R_{\odot}^{2}}{d^{2}}=
\Bigl[\sin\!\bigl(\tfrac{\theta}{2}\bigr)\Bigr]^{2}
\simeq\Bigl(\frac{\theta}{2}\Bigr)^{2}.
\]

Hence  

\[
F_\odot = \sigma T_{S}^{4}\,
          \Bigl(\frac{\theta}{2}\Bigr)^{2}.
\tag{2}
\]

A fraction \(\varepsilon\) of the incident solar radiation is reflected by the Earth (planetary albedo);
only the remaining fraction \((1-\varepsilon)\) is absorbed.   
If the Earth’s surface has a uniform temperature \(T_{0}\) and behaves as a black‑body emitter, the global radiative balance reads  

\[
(1-\varepsilon)\,F_\odot \;\underbrace{\pi R_{E}^{2}}_{\text{projected area}}
      = \underbrace{4\pi R_{E}^{2}}_{\text{total area}}\;
        \sigma T_{0}^{4}.
\]

Cancelling common factors and inserting Eq.(2),

\[
(1-\varepsilon)\,\sigma T_{S}^{4}
            \Bigl(\frac{\theta}{2}\Bigr)^{2}
       = 4\,\sigma T_{0}^{4},
\]

which gives the desired relation

\[
\boxed{
     T_{S}=T_{0}\,
           \Biggl[\frac{4}{
                 (1-\varepsilon)
                \bigl(\tfrac{\theta}{2}\bigr)^{2}}
           \Biggr]^{1/4}
    } .
\tag{3}
\]

---

### Numerical estimate   

Take “reasonable’’ terrestrial values  

| quantity | symbol | numerical value |
|----------|--------|----------------|
| Mean surface temperature (no strong greenhouse correction) | \(T_{0}\) | \(2.55\times10^{2}\ {\rm K}\) (effective Earth temperature) |
| Planetary albedo | \(\varepsilon\) | \(0.30\) |
| Apparent solar diameter | \(\theta\) | \(0.53^\circ = 9.25\times10^{-3}\ {\rm rad}\) |

Compute  

\[
\Bigl(\frac{\theta}{2}\Bigr)^{2}
         =(4.63\times10^{-3})^{2}=2.14\times10^{-5},
\]
\[
\frac{4}{(1-\varepsilon)(\theta/2)^{2}}
   =\frac{4}{0.70\times2.14\times10^{-5}}
   \approx 2.68\times10^{5}.
\]

Taking the fourth root,

\[
\bigl[2.68\times10^{5}\bigr]^{1/4}\simeq 22.6 .
\]

Finally  

\[
T_{S}\simeq 2.55\times10^{2}\ {\rm K}\times 22.6
          \approx 5.8\times10^{3}\ {\rm K}.
\]

Thus the crude radiative‑balance argument predicts  

\[
\boxed{T_{S}\sim 6\times10^{3}\ {\rm K}},
\]

which is remarkably close (within ∼10 %) to the measured photospheric temperature of the Sun,
\(T_{\odot}^{\rm real}\simeq 5.78\times10^{3}\ {\rm K}\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

**(b)   Why a glass‑house is warmer than the outdoors and how hot it can become**

Glass is almost completely transparent to the short‑wavelength solar spectrum (visible light),
but it strongly absorbs or reflects the longer‑wavelength infrared radiation that objects at ordinary temperatures emit.  

Consequences:

* Sunlight enters the house virtually unhindered and heats the floor, plants, air, … .
* The heated interior emits infrared photons; these photons encounter the glass pane, are mostly reflected back into the interior or are absorbed and later re‑radiated downward.
* Hence the rate at which thermal energy leaves the house is reduced compared with a bare open field – the classic **greenhouse effect**.  
In steady state the interior temperature rises until the upward infrared flux through the glazed ceiling equals the net solar power admitted.

---

### Upper bound on the attainable indoor temperature

Consider an idealised sealed greenhouse whose glazing:
* transmits the entire solar band (transmissivity \(\tau_{\rm s}\approx 1\)),
* is totally opaque to infrared (absorptivity/emissivity \(\alpha_{\rm ir}=1\)),  
and neglect any conductive losses.

Denote by \(A_{\rm win}\) the area of the window (or roof) and by \(A_{\rm flr}\) the floor area that receives the solar illumination.  
The absorbed solar power is  

\[
P_{\rm abs}= (1-\varepsilon)\,F_\odot\,A_{\rm win},
\]

where \(\varepsilon\) now represents the reflection of the incident solar beam by the glass (typically very small).

When the interior reaches a uniform temperature \(T_{\rm int}\), it loses energy solely by infrared radiation through the window:

\[
P_{\rm loss}= \sigma T_{\rm int}^{4}\,A_{\rm win}.
\]

Steady state requires \(P_{\rm abs}=P_{\rm loss}\), whence  

\[
\sigma T_{\rm int}^{4}= (1-\varepsilon)F_\odot
                     = (1-\varepsilon)\,
                       \sigma T_{S}^{4}
                       \Bigl(\frac{\theta}{2}\Bigr)^{2}.
\]

Therefore the maximal achievable temperature satisfies  

\[
\boxed{
   T_{\max}=T_{S}\,
            \Bigl[(1-\varepsilon)
                  \Bigl(\frac{\theta}{2}\Bigr)^{2}
             \Bigr]^{1/4}
        } .
\tag{4}
\]

Using the same numbers as in part (a) but taking \(\varepsilon\to 0\) (perfectly transmitting glass) gives  

\[
T_{\max}\approx T_{S}\,
               \Bigl(\frac{\theta}{2}\Bigr)^{1/2}
            \approx 5800\ {\rm K}\times 0.07
            \approx 400\ {\rm K}\;( \sim 130^{\circ}{\rm C}),
\]

so—even under unrealistically optimistic optical properties—a passive glass house cannot be heated arbitrarily high; the ceiling acts as a small “window” to space that caps the interior temperature at a few hundred kelvin.  

Real structures have additional losses (conduction through frame, ventilation, imperfect sealing), so practical indoor temperatures lie typically between the outdoor ambient (\(~290\ {\rm K}\)) and about \(320\!-\!340\ {\rm K}\) (∼50–70 °C) on sunny days.

> **Summary:**  
> • The Sun’s surface temperature follows from equating the absorbed solar flux on Earth with Earth’s own black‑body emission, yielding \(T_{S}\approx 6\times10^{3}\,\mathrm{K}\).  
> • A glass house stays hotter than the surrounding air because the glass lets in short‑wave solar radiation but blocks the long‑wave infrared reradiated by the warmed interior—the greenhouse effect.  
> • Even an ideal, perfectly insulating glass enclosure cannot exceed the temperature dictated by radiative balance, Eq.(4); numerically this limit is a few hundred kelvin above ambient, far below the Sun’s temperature.

### (a)   Particle‑energy spectrum for an ideal Bose gas  

The one–particle eigenstates of a free particle in a cube \(L\times L\times L\) (periodic or hard wall b.c.) are labelled by the wave vector  
\[
{\bf k}= \frac{2\pi}{L}\,(n_x,n_y,n_z)\qquad 
(n_i=0,\pm1,\pm2,\dots )
\]
with single‑particle energy  

\[
\varepsilon_{\mathbf{k}}=\frac{{\hbar ^2k^{\,2}}}{2m}.
\]

Counting the number of states whose energies lie between \(\varepsilon\) and
\(\varepsilon+d\varepsilon\) gives the **density of states**
\[
g(\varepsilon)\,d\varepsilon=
\underbrace{
\frac{V}{4\pi^{2}}\left(\frac{2m}{\hbar^{2}}\right)^{3/2}
}_{=:A}\,
\sqrt{\varepsilon }\;d\varepsilon .
\tag{1}
\]

For indistinguishable bosons the mean occupation of each state follows the
Bose–Einstein distribution  

\[
f_{\rm B}(\varepsilon)=\frac{1}{
e^{\beta (\varepsilon-\mu)}-1},
\qquad\beta\equiv\frac{1}{k_{\mathrm B}T},
\]

so that the **average number of particles with energy in the interval**
\( [\varepsilon ,\varepsilon+d\varepsilon]\) is  

\[
\boxed{%
n(\varepsilon)\,d\varepsilon =
\frac{V}{4\pi^{2}}
\Bigl(\frac{2m}{\hbar^{2}}\Bigr)^{3/2}
\frac{\sqrt{\varepsilon }}{e^{\beta(\varepsilon-\mu)}-1}\;
d\varepsilon } .
\tag{2}
\]

Equation (2) contains the required variables:
mass \(m\), energy \(\varepsilon\), temperature \(T\),
chemical potential \(\mu\), volume \(V\) and fundamental constants.

\qquad d\gg\lambda_T ,

e^{-\beta(\varepsilon-\mu)}\,d\varepsilon .
\tag{3}

Eq.(3) is precisely the product “density of states × Maxwell–Boltzmann

classical result.

### (a) Physical meaning of \(a\) and \(b\)
