  Real molecules possess a finite hard–core radius. Two molecules cannot approach closer than roughly twice their own radii, therefore a fraction of the total geometric volume is unavailable for translational motion.  For one mole the “free” volume is reduced from \(V\) to

When two particles interact, the average attractive force acting on any particle is proportional to the probability of finding another particle nearby, i.e. to the **pair density**
  \[
  \rho_{\rm pairs}\propto n^{2},\qquad n=\frac{N}{V}.
  \]
  Consequently the pressure reduction caused by these attractions varies as \(n^{2}\sim 1/V^{2}\); the coefficient of proportionality is denoted by \(a\):
  \[
  p_{\rm corr}= -\,\frac{a}{V^{2}} .
  \]

Hence the correction to the pressure appears with an inverse‑square dependence on the molar volume.

For a single mole,
\[
dF=-S\,dT-p\,dV .
\]

\[

-\int_{V_{1}}^{V_{2}}p(T,V)\,dV } .
\]

\]

\[

\Delta F &=
-\!\int_{V_{1}}^{V_{2}}
\biggl[\frac{RT}{V-b}-\frac{a}{V^{2}}\biggr]\!dV \\[3pt]
&=-
RT\int_{V_{1}}^{V_{2}}\frac{dV}{V-b}+a\int_{V_{1}}^{V_{2}}\frac{dV}{V^{2}}\\[3pt]

RT\;\bigl[\ln (V-b)\bigr]_{V_{1}}^{V_{2}}
      +a\;\bigl[-\tfrac{1}{V}\bigr]_{V_{1}}^{V_{2}}\\[3pt]
&= -RT\;
     \ln\!\frac{V_{2}-b}{\,V_{1}-b\,}
    +a\Bigl(\frac{1}{V_{1}}-\frac{1}{V_{2}}\Bigr).
\end{aligned}

\[

\displaystyle

+a\Bigl(\frac{1}{V_{1}}-\frac{1}{V_{2}}\Bigr)

With (1) and keeping \(L_{0}=L_{0}(T)\) fixed during the integration,

\[
\begin{aligned}

\int F\,{\rm d}L+g(T)\\[2mm]
&=aT\!\int\!
\Bigl[\frac{L}{L_{0}}-\frac{L_{0}^{2}}{L^{2}}\Bigr]{\rm d}L+g(T) \\[2mm]
&=aT\Bigl[\frac{L^{2}}{2L_{0}}+\frac{L_{0}^{2}}{L}\Bigr]+g(T).
\end{aligned}
\tag{3}
\]

          -g'(T) .
\end{aligned}}
\tag{4}
\]

Introducing the thermal‑expansion coefficient

S=a\,(T\alpha _0-1)\frac{L^{2}}{2L_{0}}
     -a\,(1+2T\alpha _0)\frac{L_{0}^{2}}{L}

\]

## (a) Heat absorbed in an **isothermal**, reversible stretching   
\(L:L_{0}\rightarrow 2L_{0}\)

Along an isotherm \(T={\rm const}\),

\[
Q_{\text{rev}}=\int T\,{\rm d}S=T\Delta S ,
\qquad 
\Delta S=S(L=2L_{0},T)-S(L=L_{0},T).
\]

Only the \(L\)‑dependent parts of (5) contribute; the term \(-g'(T)\) cancels.
Writing \(L=xL_{0}\;(x\ge 1)\),

                -(1+2T\alpha _0)\frac{1}{x}\Bigr].
\]

Evaluating at \(x=2\) and \(x=1\),

\[
\Delta S=aL_{0}\Bigl[\frac{5}{2}T\alpha _0-1\Bigr].
\]

Consequently

\[
\boxed{%
Q = T\Delta S
       = aL_{0}\Bigl(\frac{5}{2}\,\alpha _0 T^{2}-T\Bigr)}
\tag{6}
\]

which expresses the heat supplied to the cylinder in terms of the stated
parameters.

## (b) Elastocaloric coefficient \(\displaystyle\Bigl(\frac{\partial T}{\partial L}\Bigr)_{S}\)

Setting the entropy variation to zero,

\[
0={\rm d}S
   =\Bigl(\frac{\partial S}{\partial T}\Bigr)_{L}{\rm d}T
    +\Bigl(\frac{\partial S}{\partial L}\Bigr)_{T}{\rm d}L .
\]

Hence

\[
\Bigl(\frac{\partial T}{\partial L}\Bigr)_{S}
        =-\frac{(\partial S/\partial L)_{T}}

\tag{7}
\]

\Bigl(\frac{\partial S}{\partial L}\Bigr)_{T}

\Bigl(\frac{\partial T}{\partial L}\Bigr)_{S}

             +(1+2T\alpha _0)\frac{L_{0}^{2}}{L^{2}}\Biggr]}
\tag{9}
\]

From the explicit evaluation of \((\partial S/\partial T)_{L}\) one finds

\[
\Bigl(\frac{\partial S}{\partial T}\Bigr)_{L}

Inside the conductor the electric field vanishes (\(E_{\rm in}=0\)).  
Outside the sphere the field is purely radial,

\[
E_{\rm out}(r)=\frac{Q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}\,r^{2}} .
\]

The normal component of the Maxwell stress tensor gives the outward pressure

\[

    =\frac{\varepsilon_{0}}{2}E_{\rm out}^{\,2}
    =\frac{1}{2\varepsilon_{0}}
      \left(\frac{Q}{4\pi r^{2}}\right)^{2}.
\]

Hence  

\[
P_{\!e}= \frac{Q^{2}}{32\pi^{2}\varepsilon_{0}\,r^{4}} .
\tag{1}
\]

---

At equilibrium the outward electrostatic pressure balances the inward pressure
difference:

\[
\boxed{\;\Delta p=P_{\!e}\;}
     \qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad 
\Delta p=\frac{Q^{2}}{32\pi^{2}\varepsilon_{0}\,r^{4}} .
\tag{2}
\]

---

The electric potential of an isolated conducting sphere is

\[
\phi = \frac{Q}{4\pi\varepsilon_{0}\,r},
\qquad\Rightarrow\qquad   
Q = 4\pi\varepsilon_{0}\,r\,\phi .
\tag{3}
\]

Insert (3) into (2):

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta p &=
\frac{(4\pi\varepsilon_{0}r\phi)^{2}}
       {32\pi^{2}\varepsilon_{0}\,r^{4}}\\[4pt]
&= \frac{16\pi^{2}\varepsilon_{0}^{2}r^{2}\phi^{2}}
        {32\pi^{2}\varepsilon_{0}r^{4}} \\[4pt]

\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle \Delta p = \frac{\varepsilon_{0}\,\phi^{2}}{2\,r^{2}} }
\]

or equivalently  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle r = \sqrt{\frac{\varepsilon_{0}\,\phi^{2}}{2\,\Delta p}},\qquad
\phi = \sqrt{\frac{2\,\Delta p\,r^{2}}{\varepsilon_{0}}}.}
\]

### (a) Spectral energy density \(u(\omega ,T)\)

Inside a cubic cavity of side \(L\) the allowed wave vectors are   

\[
{\bf k}= \frac{\pi}{L}(n_x,n_y,n_z ),\qquad n_i=1,2,\dots 
\]

Each normal mode has two independent transverse polarisations, so the **density of states**
(per unit volume, per interval \(d\omega\)) is  

\[
g(\omega )\,d\omega=
\underbrace{2}_{\text{pol.}}\;
\frac{V}{(2\pi)^3}\,
4\pi k^{2}\,dk
      =\frac{\omega ^2}{\pi ^2c^{3}}\,d\omega ,
\]
where we used \(|{\bf k}|=\omega /c\) and \(dk=d\omega /c\).

For a bosonic mode of frequency \(\omega\) the mean occupation number at temperature
\(T\) is given by the Planck factor  

\[
\langle n\rangle_{\omega}
   =\frac{1}{e^{\beta\hbar\omega }-1},
   \qquad \beta\equiv\frac{1}{k_{B}T}.
\]

Hence the mean energy carried by one such mode is  

\[
\varepsilon (\omega )
    =\hbar\omega \;\langle n\rangle_{\omega }
    =\frac{\hbar\omega}{e^{\beta\hbar\omega }-1}.
\]

Multiplying the energy per mode by the number of modes per unit volume gives the
spectral energy density:

\[
\boxed{
u(\omega ,T)\,d\omega =
\left[\frac{\omega ^2}{\pi ^2c^{3}}\right]\!
        \frac{\hbar\omega}{e^{\hbar\omega/k_{B}T}-1}\,d\omega
     =\frac{\hbar\,\omega ^3}{\pi ^2c^{3}}
       \frac{d\omega}{e^{\hbar\omega/k_{B}T}-1}
}.
\]

This is the familiar *Planck* spectrum written in terms of the angular frequency
\(\omega\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (b) Temperature dependence of the total energy density

The total electromagnetic energy per unit volume is obtained by integrating over all frequencies,

\[
u(T)=\int_{0}^{\infty}u(\omega ,T)\,d\omega
     =\frac{\hbar}{\pi ^2c^{3}}
       \int_{0}^{\infty}
          \frac{\omega ^3}{e^{\hbar\omega/k_{B}T}-1}\,d\omega .
\]

Introduce the dimensionless variable \(x=\hbar\omega/k_{B}T\):
\[
\omega =\frac{k_{B}T}{\hbar}x,\qquad d\omega =\frac{k_{B}T}{\hbar}dx .
\]

Then  

\[
u(T)=\frac{\hbar}{\pi ^2c^{3}}
      \Bigl(\frac{k_{B}T}{\hbar}\Bigr)^{4}
      \int_{0}^{\infty}\!\! \frac{x^{3}}{e^{x}-1}\,dx .
\]

The integral is a pure number:
\[
\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{x^{3}}{e^{x}-1}\,dx
      =\Gamma(4)\zeta(4)
      =6\cdot\frac{\pi ^4}{90}
      =\frac{\pi ^4}{15}.
\]

Therefore  

\[
u(T)=\frac{\hbar}{\pi ^2c^{3}}
      \Bigl(\frac{k_{B}T}{\hbar}\Bigr)^{4}
      \frac{\pi ^4}{15}
    =\frac{\pi ^2 k_{B}^{4}}{15\,\hbar^{3}c^{3}}\,T^{4}.
\]

Consequently the total electromagnetic energy density scales as the fourth power of the temperature – the well‑known Stefan–Boltzmann law for the energy density.

\[
\boxed{\,u(T)=a\,T^{4},\qquad 
       a=\frac{\pi ^2 k_{B}^{4}}{15\,\hbar^{3}c^{3}}\, }.
\]

(The corresponding radiative flux through a surface would be \(\sigma T^{4}\) with
\(\sigma=a c/4\).)

### (a) High‑temperature limit \(T\to\infty\)

When \(\beta\hbar\omega_k\ll 1\),

\[
\frac{\hbar\omega_k}{e^{\beta\hbar\omega_k}-1}=k_{\mathrm B}T-
\frac12\hbar\omega_k+\mathcal O[(\beta\hbar\omega_k)^2].
\]

Keeping only the leading term,

\[
U\simeq \underbrace{N}_{\text{one mode per particle}}k_{\mathrm B}T .
\]

Consequently  

\[
\boxed{c_v\equiv\frac{1}{L}\,\frac{{\rm d}U}{{\rm d}T}
      =\frac{N k_{\mathrm B}}{L}= \frac{k_{\mathrm B}}{a}}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
c_v\stackrel{T\to\infty}{=}k_{\mathrm B}\;( {\rm per\;particle}) .
\]

(The result is the familiar Dulong–Petit value.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (b) Low‑temperature limit \(T\to 0\)

For long wavelengths \(|k|\ll 1\),

\[
\omega(k)=2\bar\omega\Big|\sin\frac{k}{2}\Big|
        \simeq \bar\omega |k|,
\qquad\Rightarrow\qquad 
v_s\equiv\frac{{\rm d}\omega}{{\rm d}k}\Big|_{k=0}= \bar\omega .
\]

Thus the **density of states per unit length** is

\[
g(\omega)=\frac{1}{2\pi}\frac{{\rm d}k}{{\rm d}\omega}
         \times 2=
         \frac{1}{\pi v_s}= \frac{1}{\pi\bar\omega},
\qquad (\omega\le\omega_{\max}),
\]
i.e. it is *frequency‑independent* for the acoustic branch.

At very low temperatures only the low‑energy part matters, allowing us

\[

     =\frac{1}{\pi\bar\omega}
       \int_{0}^{\infty}{\rm d}\omega\;
       \frac{\hbar\omega}{e^{\beta\hbar\omega}-1}.
\]

With the change of variable \(x=\beta\hbar\omega\),

\[

      \int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{x\,{\rm d}x}{e^{x}-1}
    =\frac{1}{\pi\bar\omega}\,

      \frac{\pi^{2}}{6}
    =\frac{\pi}{6\hbar\bar\omega}(k_{\mathrm B}T)^{2}.

\[

    =\frac{\pi k_{\mathrm B}^{2}}{3\hbar\bar\omega}\,T .

A\,\omega^{-\alpha}T^{\gamma},
\qquad\text{with }\;
\boxed{\alpha=1},\qquad\boxed{\gamma=1}.

### (b)   Closure‑density (“no‑more‑than‑closed”) bound on the neutrino temperature  

If the Universe contains at most the critical density,
\[
\rho_{\rm crit}= \frac{3H_{0}^{2}}{8\pi G}\simeq 8.5\times10^{-10}\ {\rm J\,m^{-3}},
\]
then the energy density contributed by a *relativistic* neutrino gas must obey  
\(\rho_{\nu}\le\rho_{\rm crit}\).

For a relativistic Fermi‑Dirac gas with zero chemical potential,

\[
\rho_{\nu}= \frac{7}{8}\,N_{\!\rm eff}\,\left(\frac{k_{\!B}T_{\nu}}{\hbar c}\right)^{4},
\qquad 
\rho_{\gamma}= \left(\frac{k_{\!B}T_{\gamma}}{\hbar c}\right)^{4}.
\]

Using the observed fact that the photon background supplies only
\(10^{-6}\) of the critical density,
\[
\frac{\rho_{\gamma}}{\rho_{\rm crit}}\simeq10^{-6},
\]
and taking the standard value \(N_{\!\rm eff}\simeq3\),

\[
\frac{\rho_{\nu}}{\rho_{\gamma}}
      =\frac{7}{8}N_{\!\rm eff}\Bigl(\frac{T_{\nu}}{T_{\gamma}}\Bigr)^{4}
      \le 10^{6}.
\]

Solving for the temperature ratio,

\[
\Bigl(\frac{T_{\nu}}{T_{\gamma}}\Bigr)
     \le \biggl[\frac{8}{7N_{\!\rm eff}}\,10^{6}\biggr]^{1/4}
     \approx \bigl(3.8\times10^{5}\bigr)^{1/4}
     \sim 2.5\times10^{1}.
\]

With the measured CMB temperature \(T_{\gamma}=2.725\) K,

\[
\boxed{T_{\nu}\;\lesssim\; (2\mbox{--}3)\times10^{2}\ {\rm K}} .
\]

(The bound relaxes somewhat if the neutrinos are already non‑relativistic, in which case their rest‑mass energy dominates; then the simple \(T^{4}\) scaling is replaced by the condition \((3/2)nk_{\!B}T\lesssim\rho_{\rm crit}\), yielding a still weaker limit of order \(10^{5}\) K.)

Consider a Euclidean space with \(n\) spatial dimensions.  
All thermodynamic quantities can be obtained from the phase–space density of single‑particle states,
which in \(n\) dimensions grows as  

\[
g(\mathbf{k})\,{\rm d}^{n}\!k=\frac{V}{(2\pi )^{n}}\, {\rm d}^{n}\!k .
\]

The factor \(V\) denotes the hyper‑volume of the system.   
From this state density one evaluates the relevant integrals for photons, phonons and a mono‑atomic ideal gas.



--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 1. Black‑body radiation – exponent \(\boxed{\alpha=n+1}\)

A photon has two transverse polarisation states independent of \(n\); its dispersion relation is 
\(E=c\hbar |\mathbf{k}|.\)  
The energy density is

\[
u(T)=\frac{2}{(2\pi)^n}
      \int_{{\mathbb R}^{n}}\!\!
        \frac{\hbar c|\mathbf{k}|}{
               e^{\beta\hbar c|\mathbf{k|}}-1 }\,{\rm d}^{n}k ,
   \qquad \beta=\frac{1}{k_{\mathrm B}T}.
\]

Write the integral in spherical coordinates (\({\rm d}^{n}k=S_{n-1}k^{\,n-1}{\rm d}k\)) :

\[
u(T)=\frac{2S_{n-1}}{(2\pi)^n}
     \int_{0}^{\infty}\!
       \frac{\hbar ck^{\,n}}
            {e^{\beta\hbar ck}-1}\,{\rm d}k .
\]

Introduce the variable \(x=\beta\hbar ck\;(dx=\beta\hbar c\,dk)\):

\[
u(T)=\frac{2 S_{n-1}}{(2\pi)^n}
      \left(k_{\mathrm B}T\right)^{n+1}
      \underbrace{
          \frac{1}{(\hbar c)^{n}}
           \int_{0}^{\infty}\!
                \frac{x^{\,n}}{e^{x}-1}\,{\rm d}x}_{\displaystyle\text{pure number }
                 =\Gamma(n+1)\,\zeta(n+1)} .
\]

Everything except the power of \(T\) collapses into constants depending on \(n\).
Hence  

\[
\boxed{u(T)\propto T^{\,n+1}},\qquad\Longrightarrow\quad\boxed{\alpha=n+1}.
\]


--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 2. Low‑temperature Debye specific heat – exponent \(\boxed{\beta=n}\)

Acoustic phonons also obey a linear dispersion \(\omega=v_s k\) (with sound speed \(v_s\)).  
Counting normal modes up to a maximum wave‑vector \(k_D\) (the Debye cut‑off) gives the **density of states**

\[
g(\omega){\rm d}\omega=
    \frac{n V}{(2\pi)^n}S_{n-1}
    \Bigl(\frac{\omega}{v_s}\Bigr)^{n-1}
    \frac{{\rm d}\omega}{v_s},
\]
so that \(g(\omega)\propto\omega^{\,n-1}\).

The total internal energy carried by these bosonic excitations is

\[
U(T)=\int_{0}^{\infty}\! \frac{\hbar\omega}{e^{\beta\hbar\omega}-1}\;
                     g(\omega)\,{\rm d}\omega
     \;\propto\;
     \int_{0}^{\infty}\!
         \frac{\omega^{\,n}}{e^{\beta\hbar\omega}-1}\,{\rm d}\omega .
\]

Again change variables \(x=\beta\hbar\omega\),

\[
U(T)\propto (k_{\mathrm B}T)^{\,n+1}
          \int_{0}^{\infty}\!\frac{x^{\,n}}{e^{x}-1}\,{\rm d}x .
\]

\[
C_V =\frac{\partial U}{\partial T}
     \propto (k_{\mathrm B})^{\,n+1}(n+1)T^{\,n}
     \;\Longrightarrow\;
     \boxed{C_V\propto T^{\,n}},
\]

so the low‑temperature Debye law becomes  

\[
\boxed{\beta=n}.
\]

For \(n=3\) we recover the familiar \(C_V\sim T^{3}\).

A classical monatomic gas possesses only translational kinetic energy.
Each degree of freedom contributes \(\tfrac12k_{\mathrm B}T\) to the average molecular energy

\[

\[

c_P = c_V + k_{\mathrm B}= \frac{n}{2}k_{\mathrm B}+k_{\mathrm B}
     = \frac{n+2}{2}k_{\mathrm B}.

\[

Let  

* \(N=10\,000\) – total number of bacteria kept constant by the predator,  
* \(R_t\) – number of red bacteria after the \(t^{\text{th}}\) “cycle’’ (one hour : everybody duplicates once, afterwards the predator removes exactly \(N\) cells chosen at random),
* \(x_t=R_t/N\) – red‑fraction,
* a “cycle’’ therefore consists of a **birth–death event** identical to the elementary step of a Moran model.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (a)   Long‑time distribution of the number of reds  

During a cycle the following happens  

1. All cells duplicate ⇒ the population momentarily contains \(2R_t\) reds and \(2(N-R_t)\) greens;
2. The predator kills \(N\) cells chosen uniformly at random.

Hence conditional on the present value \(R_t=r\),

\[
R_{t+1}\;\sim\; {\rm HypGeom}
      \bigl(M=2N,\;K=2r,\;n=N\bigr).
\tag{1}
\]

The Markov chain \(\{R_t\}_{t\ge 0}\) possesses two absorbing states,
\(R=0\) (only green left) and \(R=N\) (only red left);
once reached the dynamics stops because (1) never moves away from an
absorbing boundary.

Because the process is completely neutral (the predator selects at random,
and both colours replicate identically), the classical result for a neutral Moran walk applies:

\[
\boxed{
\Pr\!\left\{R_{\infty}=N\right\}= \frac{R_0}{N},\qquad 
\Pr\!\left\{R_{\infty}=0\right\}=1-\frac{R_0}{N}.
}
\]

With the initial condition \(R_0=5\,000\) we obtain  

\[
\Pr\{R_\infty =10\,000\}= \tfrac12 ,\qquad   
\Pr\{R_\infty =0\}= \tfrac12 .
\]

All other intermediate values have asymptotic probability zero.  
In words: **after a sufficiently long time the colony ends up either entirely red or entirely green, each with probability ½.**

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (b)   How long before the above picture holds ?

For a neutral Moran process the mean time to absorption (measured in cycles) when the initial red‐frequency is \(x=R_0/N\) is  [^1][^2]

\[
\mathbb{E}[T_{\mathrm{abs}}]= -4N\Bigl[x\ln x +(1-x)\ln(1-x)\Bigr].
\tag{2}
\]

Putting \(N=10\,000\) and \(x=\tfrac12\),

\[
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}[T_{\mathrm{abs}}]
&= -4\times10^{4}\,[\tfrac12\ln\tfrac12+\tfrac12\ln\tfrac12]\\
&= 4\times10^{4}\,\ln 2\\
&\approx 2.77\times10^{4}\ \hbox{cycles}.
\end{aligned}
\]

One cycle lasts exactly one hour, thus

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\mathbb{E}[T_{\mathrm{abs}}]\;\approx\;2.8\times10^{4}\ {\rm h}
          \;\approx\;1.2\times10^{3}\ {\rm days}
          \;\approx\;3.2\ {\rm yr}. }
\]

(The distribution of the absorption time is broad; nevertheless the order of a few years is typical.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (c)   Effect of a 1 % predator preference for reds  

Assume the predator now kills a red cell with probability \(1.01\) times the baseline and a green cell with probability \(0.99\) times the baseline (renormalised so that the overall killing rate remains one cell per hour).  
This creates a **selection pressure against reds**.  
Denote the corresponding selective disadvantage by \(s\;(s<0)\).  
A convenient linearisation gives  

\[
s\simeq -0.01 .
\]

#### (i) New fixation probability  

For a Moran process with constant selection coefficient \(s\) the fixation
probability of reds started at frequency \(x\) is ([Kimura 1962])

\[
u(x)=\frac{1-e^{-2Nsx}}{1-e^{-2Ns}},\qquad N=10^{4}.
\tag{3}
\]

Insert \(s=-0.01\) (\(Ns=-100\)) and \(x=0.5\):

\[
u(0.5)=\frac{1-e^{100}}{1-e^{200}}
       \;\approx\;e^{-100}\;\approx\;3.7\times10^{-44},
\]

so the probability of ending with an all‑red colony becomes astronomically small; practically the colony will finish **all green**.

#### (ii) Mean time to absorption  

When selection dominates genetic drift (\(|Ns|\gg 1\)), the average
fixation/extinction time scales as  

\[
\mathbb{E}[T]\;\approx\;\frac{1}{|s|}\,\ln\!(N) ,
\tag{4}
\]

which for \(|s|=0.01\) and \(N=10^{4}\) gives  

\[
\mathbb{E}[T]\;\approx\; \frac{1}{0.01}\times\ln(10^{4})

                     \;\approx\;38\ {\rm days}.

Let's craft response.assistantfinal**Carnot Cycle – definition**

A *Carnot cycle* is the most efficient possible cyclic process that operates between two thermal reservoirs at fixed temperatures \(T_{\mathrm H}\;(>T_{\mathrm C})\).  
It consists of **four reversible steps**:

| Step | Process                              | Heat exchange | Temperature |
|------|-------------------------------------|---------------|-------------|
| 1 → 2| Isothermal expansion (heat absorbed) | \(+\,Q_{\rm H}>0\) | \(T=T_{\rm H}\) |
| 2 → 3| Adiabatic (reversible) expansion      | none          | cools from \(T_{\rm H}\) to \(T_{\rm C}\) |
| 3 → 4| Isothermal compression (heat rejected)| \(-\,Q_{\rm C}<0\) | \(T=T_{\rm C}\) |
| 4 → 1| Adiabatic (reversible) compression    | none          | heats back to \(T_{\rm H}\) |

Because each leg is reversible, the total entropy change of the working fluid after one complete circuit is zero,
\[
\Delta S_{\text {cycle}}=\frac{Q_{\rm H}}{T_{\rm H}}-\frac{Q_{\rm C}}{T_{\rm C}}=0 .
\tag{1}
\]

---

### 1. Sketches  

Below are schematic drawings (any scale‑consistent sketch will do).

#### (a) \(p\!-\!V\) diagram  

```
        ^ p
        |
   2----|-----------\
       /            \
  1---/              \--3
     \                /
      \--------------/
               4 -----> V
```

* 1→2 : isothermal expansion at \(T_{\rm H}\); curve follows \(pV=nRT_{\rm H}\).
* 2→3 : adiabatic expansion (\(pV^{\gamma}= {\rm const}\)), steeper than the isotherm.
* 3→4 : isothermal compression at \(T_{\rm C}\) (lower pressure line).
* 4→1 : adiabatic compression returning to the original state.

The closed loop’s interior represents the **net work output**
\(\displaystyle W_{\rm out}= \oint pdV\).

#### (b) \(S\!-\!T\) diagram  

```
         T
         ^
         |
   +Qc --|-----------------
         |                 |
         |                 |
   +Qh --|_________________|--> S
           S1          S2
```

* The horizontal segments (constant entropy) are the **adiabats** (steps 2→3 and 4→1): no heat flow ⇒ \(dS=0\).
* The vertical legs represent the **isothermals**, where the system absorbs/rejects heat:
  \[
  \Delta S_{12}= \frac{Q_{\rm H}}{T_{\rm H}},\qquad 
  \Delta S_{34}= -\frac{Q_{\rm C}}{T_{\rm C}} .
  \]
The rectangular shape reflects the fact that the entropy changes occur only during the isothermal parts while the temperature stays fixed.

---

### 2. Thermodynamic relations for an ideal–gas working substance  

Assume the working fluid behaves as an ideal gas (\(pV=nRT\)).  
For the two isothermal branches,

\[
\begin{aligned}
Q_{\rm H}&=W_{12}=n R T_{\rm H}\ln\!\left(\frac{V_2}{V_1}\right),\\[4pt]
Q_{\rm C}&=-W_{34}=n R T_{\rm C}\ln\!\left(\frac{V_3}{V_4}\right),
\end{aligned}
\tag{2}
\]

where the signs follow the convention “positive when entering the system”.

During the adiabatic legs the relation \(TV^{\gamma-1}= {\rm const}\) holds (\(\gamma=C_p/C_v\)):
\[
T_{\rm H}V_2^{\gamma-1}=T_{\rm C}V_3^{\gamma-1},
\qquad
T_{\rm C}V_4^{\gamma-1}=T_{\rm H}V_1^{\gamma-1}.
\tag{3}
\]

Dividing these two equations gives

\[
\boxed{\;\frac{V_2}{V_1}= \frac{V_3}{V_4}\;}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\ln\!\Bigl(\tfrac{V_2}{V_1}\Bigr)=\ln\!\Bigl(\tfrac{V_3}{V_4}\Bigr)\equiv \ln r ,
\tag{4}
\]
so both logarithmic factors appearing in Eq.(2) are identical.

Consequently

\[
\frac{|Q_{\rm C}|}{Q_{\rm H}}
=
\frac{T_{\rm C}}{T_{\rm H}}\;
\frac{\ln r}{\ln r}
=
\frac{T_{\rm C}}{T_{\rm H}},
\tag{5}
\]
which also follows directly from the entropy balance (Eq.\,(1)).

---

### 3. Net work and efficiency  

From energy conservation for a complete cycle (\(\Delta U=0\))

\[
W_{\rm out}=Q_{\rm H}+Q_{\rm C}=Q_{\rm H}-|Q_{\rm C}|.
\tag{6}
\]

Using (5),

\[
W_{\rm out}=Q_{\rm H}\biggl(1-\frac{T_{\rm C}}{T_{\rm H}}\biggr).
\tag{7}
\]

The **thermal efficiency**—the fraction of supplied heat converted into useful work—is therefore

\[
\boxed{
\eta_{\rm Carnot}= \frac{W_{\rm out}}{Q_{\rm H}}
                  = 1-\frac{T_{\rm C}}{T_{\rm H}} } .
\tag{8}
\]

This expression depends **only** on the absolute temperatures of the two reservoirs; it does not depend on the details of the working substance nor on the size of the cycle. It sets the upper bound for any heat engine operating between those two temperatures (Second Law of thermodynamics).

---

## Final Result  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\eta_{\text{Carnot}} = 1-\frac{T_{\rm C}}{T_{\rm H}} }
\]

Let's craft nicely.assistantfinal**(a)   Fundamental assumptions**

|                     | **Maxwell–Boltzmann (MB)**                              | **Fermi‑Dirac (FD)**                                   |
|---------------------|----------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------|
| Particles           | *Distinguishable* – each particle is labelled uniquely. | *Indistinguishable* – swapping two particles does not give a new microstate. |
| Quantum nature      | Treated classically; wave‑function overlap ignored.     | Full quantum treatment; antisymmetric many‑body wave‑function required. |
| Occupation numbers  | No restriction on how many particles may occupy a single‐particle state (any integer \(n_i=0,1,2,\dots\)). | **Pauli exclusion principle:** at most one fermion per quantum state (\(n_i =0\) or \(1\)). |
| Distribution formula| \(f_{\rm MB}(E)\propto e^{-E/k_{B}T}\).                 | \(f_{\rm FD}(E)=\dfrac{1}{e^{(E-\mu)/k_{B}T}+1}\), where \(\mu\) is the chemical potential (≈ the Fermi energy at low \(T\)). |

---

**(b)   Energy‑distribution functions**

For a gas of non‑interacting particles the probability density that a particle has kinetic energy \(E\) is  

\[
g(E)\,f(E),
\qquad 
g(E)\propto \sqrt{E}
\]
(the density of states for free particles in three dimensions).

Hence we plot the product \(g(E)f(E)\):

* **Maxwell–Boltzmann:**  
  \[
  P_{\rm MB}(E)\;\propto\; \sqrt{E}\,e^{-E/k_{B}T}.
  \]  
  The curve rises from zero, reaches a maximum around \(E\simeq \tfrac12 k_{B}T\) and then decays exponentially. Raising the temperature broadens the distribution and shifts its peak to a slightly larger \(E\); the height of the peak decreases.

* **Fermi‑Dirac:**  
  \[
  P_{\rm FD}(E)\;\propto\; \frac{\sqrt{E}}{e^{(E-\mu)/k_{B}T}+1 } .
  \]  
  At very low \(T\) the occupation is essentially a step function: all states below the **Fermi energy** \(E_F\approx\mu(T\!\to\!0)\) are occupied (\(P\neq0\)), while those above are empty. As \(T\) grows the step smooths into a rounded “S”‑shaped profile centred at \(E=\mu\); the width of the transition region is ≈ few \(k_{B}T\).

Below is a schematic representation (vertical axis proportional to the probability density, horizontal axis the energy \(E\)) :

```
          ^                FD (low T)
    P     |-----------|_____________________
          |            \
          |             \               FD (high T)
          |              \_____________/__________
          |                                      
          |        MB (low T)       MB (high T)
          |         /\                  /\
          |        /  \                /  \
          -------------------------------------------------> E
```

*The solid line on the left side of each pair denotes the **lower‑temperature** case; the dashed/broader line on the right denotes the **higher‑temperature** case.* In both statistics increasing \(T\) makes the distribution wider and reduces the magnitude of the peak.

---

**(c)   Specific‑heat problem of metals**

Classical MB statistics applied to conduction electrons predict, via the equipartition theorem,
\[
C_V^{\text{electrons}}\;( {\rm per\;electron}) = \frac32 k_B ,
\]
so that the molar electronic specific heat would be about \( \frac32 R \approx 12\,\mathrm{J\,mol^{-1}K^{-1}}\).
Experimentally, however, the measured specific heat of ordinary metals at room temperature is almost entirely accounted for by lattice vibrations (Debye phonons); the electronic part is tiny—of order \(10^{-2}\,\mathrm{J\,mol^{-1}K^{-1}}\)—and varies roughly linearly with temperature:
\[
C_{\text{el}} \simeq \gamma T ,\qquad \gamma\sim 1~\text{mJ\,mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-2}.
\]

**Why MB fails:**  
In a classical picture electrons are treated as independent distinguishable particles that can populate any energy level according to the Boltzmann weight. Consequently a huge number of electrons could be thermally promoted far above their ground‑state energies already at modest temperatures, yielding a large heat capacity.

**How FD resolves it:**  
Because of the Pauli exclusion principle, at \(T=0\) all available states up to the Fermi energy \(E_F\) are completely filled, forming a degenerate “Fermi sea”. Only electrons lying within an interval of order \(k_B T\) of \(E_F\) have vacant neighboring states they can jump into when the temperature changes. Thus the fraction of electrons that actually participate in thermal excitations scales as \(k_B T/E_F\ll 1\). A detailed calculation using the FD distribution gives

\[
C_{\text{el}} = \frac{\pi^2}{2}\,k_B \left(\frac{k_B T}{E_F}\right) N
               = \gamma T ,
\quad\text{with }\;
\gamma = \frac{\pi^2}{2}\, \frac{k_B^2 N}{E_F},
\]

which reproduces the experimentally observed linear‑in‑\(T\) behavior and the correct magnitude (since typical metallic \(E_F\sim 5\!-\!10\:\text{eV}\)). Hence FD statistics removes the gross overestimate produced by MB theory and correctly explains the low electronic specific heat of metals.

--- 

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{(a)} &&\text{MB : distinguishable, no occupancy limit;}\\
&&&\text{FD : indistinguishable fermions, obey Pauli exclusion.}\\[4pt]
&\text{(b)} &&\text{Plots described above; higher $T$ → broader, smoother distributions.}\\[4pt]
&\text{(c)} &&\text{MB predicts too large $C_V$ because it ignores Pauli blocking; FD restricts}\\
&&&\text{thermal excitations to $\sim k_BT$ around $E_F$, giving }C_{\rm el}\propto T\text{, in accord with experiment.}
\end{aligned}}
\]

assistantfinalWhen the air temperature falls abruptly by \( \Delta T\) below the freezing point, the newly formed ice conducts the latent‑heat released at its bottom (the water–ice interface) up to the colder air.  

Let  

* \(x(t)\) – thickness of the ice layer at time \(t\);
* \(\Lambda\) – thermal conductivity of the ice;
* \(\ell = L/V\) – latent heat per unit **volume** of ice (\({\rm J\,m^{-3}}\));
* the temperature at the water–ice interface remains at the melting temperature \(T_{m}\);
* the temperature at the ice–air surface is approximately \(T_{m}-\Delta T\) (convective resistance of the thin boundary layer is ignored).

---

### Energy balance

Heat conducted through the ice equals the latent heat liberated by solidification:

\[
q_{\text{cond}} = q_{\text{lat}}
\]

Conductive heat flux (Fourier’s law) through a slab of thickness \(x\):

\[
q_{\text{cond}}=\frac{\Lambda\,(T_{m}- (T_{m}-\Delta T))}{x}
               =\frac{\Lambda\,\Delta T}{x}.
\]

Latent heat released per unit area when the ice grows by an amount \(dx\):

\[
q_{\text{lat}} = \ell\,\frac{dx}{dt},
\]
because \(\ell\) has dimensions of energy per unit volume.

Equating both fluxes,

\[
\boxed{\;\ell\,\frac{dx}{dt}= \frac{\Lambda\,\Delta T}{x}\;}
      \qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad 
      \frac{dx}{dt}= \frac{\Lambda\,\Delta T}{\ell\,x}.
\]

---

### Solving for \(x(t)\)

Separate variables and integrate, taking \(x(0)=0\),

\[
x\,dx = \frac{\Lambda\,\Delta T}{\ell}\,dt,
\quad\Rightarrow\quad
\int_0^{x(t)} x'\,dx'= \frac{\Lambda\,\Delta T}{\ell}\int_0^{t} dt',
\]

\[
\frac{x^{2}(t)}{2}= \frac{\Lambda\,\Delta T}{\ell}\,t .
\]

Hence

\[
\boxed{\,x(t)=\sqrt{\frac{2\Lambda\,\Delta T}{\ell}\;t } }
   \qquad\bigl(\ell=L/V\bigr).
\]

---

So the ice thickness increases proportionally to the square root of time, with the proportionality containing the thermal conductivity of ice, the imposed temperature drop, and the latent heat per unit volume.

\[
\boxed{
\displaystyle 
h(t)=\sqrt{\frac{2\,\Lambda\,\Delta T}{L/V}\;t}
}
\]

\[

    =-\Delta_i\tanh (\beta\Delta_i).
\]

Hence the heat capacity contributed by this atom is  

\[

\tag{1}
\]

\[

               \operatorname{sech}^{2}\!\Bigl(\frac{\Delta}{k_{\!B}T}\Bigr)}
\tag{2}
\]

assistantfinal**(a)   Radiation pressure of an isotropic photon gas**

Consider a tiny element \(dA\) of a perfectly reflecting surface.  
Let a beam of photons arrive from direction \((\theta ,\phi )\) – \(\theta\) being the angle measured from the outward normal \({\bf n}\) of the surface.  

The energy density carried by rays travelling within the solid‑angle element \(d\Omega=\sin\theta\,d\theta\,d\phi\) is  

\[
du = \frac{u}{4\pi}\,d\Omega ,
\qquad (\text{isotropy } \Rightarrow {\rm uniform~over }4\pi).
\]

In time \(dt\) those photons travel a distance \(c\,dt\); therefore the amount of energy that strikes the area \(dA\) is  

\[
dE = cu\,\frac{\cos\theta}{4\pi}\,d\Omega \; dA dt .
\]

Each photon carries linear momentum \(p_{\gamma}=E_\gamma/c\).   
For a ray arriving under angle \(\theta\) its **normal** momentum component is 
\(p_n=(E_\gamma/c)\cos\theta\).  
Because the wall is perfectly reflecting the normal component reverses sign,
so the change of momentum delivered to the wall is  

\[
\Delta p_{n}=2\frac{E_\gamma}{c}\cos\theta .
\]

Consequently the force contributed by the bundle of directions \((\theta,\phi)\) is  

\[
dF = \frac{2}{c}\, \bigl(cu\bigr)
      \frac{\cos^{2}\!\theta}{4\pi}\,d\Omega \; dA .
\]

Dividing by the area yields the pressure contribution,

\[
dp = \frac{2u}{4\pi}\cos ^2\! \theta \, d\Omega .
\]

Integrating over all incoming directions (\(0\le\theta\le\pi/2\)) :

\[
p = \int_{{\rm hemisphere}} \frac{2u}{4\pi}\cos ^2\! \theta \, d\Omega
    =\frac{u}{2\pi}
       \int_{0}^{2\pi}\! d\phi\!
       \int_{0}^{\pi/2}\! \cos ^2\! \theta \sin\theta \, d\theta .
\]

Evaluating the angular integrals,

\[
\int_{0}^{\pi/2}\! \cos ^2\! \theta \sin\theta \, d\theta=
        \Big[-\tfrac13\cos ^3\! \theta\Big]_0^{\pi/2}= \frac13 ,
\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad
p = \frac{u}{2\pi}(2\pi)\frac13 = \boxed{\displaystyle \frac{u}{3}}\; .
\]


--------------------------------------------------------------------

**(b)   Independence of the black–body energy density on geometry and wall material**

Place a body of arbitrary shape and composition in contact with a cavity filled with electromagnetic radiation that is in complete thermal equilibrium at temperature \(T\). Let the total internal energy of the radiation be \(U\) and the cavity volume be \(V\). Define the energy density  

\[
u(T)\equiv\frac{U}{V}.
\]

*Extensivity.*  
If we take two identical cavities, labelled “1’’ and “2”, both kept at the same temperature \(T\) and join them side‑by‑side without allowing heat exchange with anything else, the combined system is again a cavity at temperature \(T\) whose volume is simply \(V_1+V_2\). In equilibrium the energies add:
\[
U_{12}=U_1+U_2 .
\]
Therefore
\[
\frac{U_{12}}{V_1+V_2}= \frac{U_1+U_2}{V_1+V_2},
\]
which shows that the ratio \(U/V\) cannot depend on how big the individual pieces are; otherwise the above equality could not hold for arbitrary choices of \(V_1,V_2\). Consequently \(u\) is a function only of the intensive parameter(s) characterising the equilibrium—here the absolute temperature \(T\).

*Material‐independence (Kirchhoff’s law).*  
Black‑body radiation obeys Kirchhoff’s theorem: in thermal equilibrium the emissivity of any surface equals its absorptivity, and the spectral radiance becomes universal—it does not contain any property of the wall material. Thus the equilibrium radiation field is completely specified by the temperature alone. Combining this physical statement with the extensivity argument forces  

\[
\boxed{u = u(T)} ,
\]
i.e. the energy density of black‑body radiation depends exclusively on the temperature and not on the cavity size nor on what the walls are made of.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

**(c)   Determination of the temperature dependence of the pressure**

From part (a) applied to black‑body radiation we already have  

\[
U = 3pV ,\qquad\text{and}\qquad p = p(T) .
\tag{1}
\]

Treat the radiation as a simple compressible fluid having no conserved particle number. Its fundamental thermodynamic identity reads  

\[
dU = T\,dS - p\,dV .
\tag{2}
\]

Using (1),

\[
dU = d(3pV)=3V\,dp+3p\,dV .
\]

Insert this into (2):

\[
3V\,dp+3p\,dV = T\,dS-p\,dV
\;\Longrightarrow\;
T\,dS = 3V\,dp+4p\,dV .
\tag{3}
\]

Since there is no intrinsic length scale besides the volume, the entropy must be extensive:
\[
S=S(T,V)=\sigma(T)\,V ,
\quad\text{with }\sigma(T)\equiv\left.\frac{\partial S}{\partial V}\right|_{T}.
\]
Hence  

\[
dS = \sigma'(T)\,V\,dT+\sigma(T)\,dV .
\]

Substituting this expression for \(dS\) into (3) and separating the differentials \(dT\) and \(dV\) give two relations:

\[
\begin{aligned}
&\underbrace{T\sigma(T)}_{ \text{coefficient of } dV}=4p ,\\[2mm]
&T\sigma'(T)\,V = 3V\,\frac{dp}{dT}.
\end{aligned}
\tag{4}
\]

From the first of Eqs.(4)

\[
p = \frac{T\,\sigma(T)}{4}\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\sigma(T)=\frac{4p}{T}.                                   \tag{5}
\]

Differentiate (5) with respect to \(T\):

\[
\sigma'(T)=\frac{4}{T}\frac{dp}{dT}-\frac{4p}{T^{2}} .
\]

Multiply by \(T\) and insert into the second Eq.(4):

\[
T\sigma'(T)=4\frac{dp}{dT}-\frac{4p}{T}=3\frac{dp}{dT}.
\]

Rearranging,

\[
\frac{dp}{dT}= \frac{4p}{T}.
\]

This ordinary differential equation integrates immediately:

\[
\frac{1}{p}\,dp = 4\,\frac{dT}{T}
\;\Longrightarrow\;
\ln p = 4\ln T + \text{const}
\;\Longrightarrow\;
p = a\,T^{4},
\tag{6}
\]

where \(a\) is an integration constant that cannot be obtained from pure thermodynamics (it contains Planck’s constant, Boltzmann’s constant, the speed of light, etc.). 

Finally, using \(U=3pV\) we obtain the familiar Stefan–Boltzmann forms  

\[
U = 3a\,T^{4}V ,\qquad 
u = \frac{U}{V}=3a\,T^{4},\qquad 
p = a\,T^{4}.
\]

---

### Final Results

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{ll}
\text{(a)} & p = \displaystyle\frac{u}{3}\\[6pt]
\text{(b)} & u = u(T)\;\; \text{(depends only on temperature)} \\[6pt]
\text{(c)} & p(T)= a\,T^{4}\qquad (a\;\hbox{constant})
\end{array}}
\]

\[

\tag{5}

\tag{6}
\]

### (b) Why do all three statistics converge at sufficiently high temperature?

A quantitative measure of quantum versus classical behaviour is the ratio of the **thermal de Broglie wavelength**
\[
\lambda_T=\frac{h}{\sqrt{2\pi mk_BT}}
\]
to the characteristic inter‑particle spacing \(d\).  

*If \(\lambda_T\ll d\)* the wave packets associated with individual particles hardly overlap; each particle behaves essentially as a localized, classically distinguishable object. Exchange symmetry—whether the overall wavefunction is symmetric (boson) or antisymmetric (fermion)—has no observable consequence because the probability amplitude for two particles to be found in the same region of space is vanishingly small. Consequently the occupation numbers obey \(\bar n_i\approx e^{-(\varepsilon_i-\mu)/k_BT}\), i.e. the Maxwell–Boltzmann law.

Conversely, when \(\lambda_T\gtrsim d\) the spatial wavefunctions start overlapping appreciably. Now the symmetrisation postulate matters:
* fermions cannot pile up in the lowest available levels (the Pauli blockade);
* bosons tend to accumulate in the same low‑energy mode (possible condensation).

Hence the crossover temperature is set implicitly by the condition
\[
\boxed{\;\lambda_T\simeq d\;}
\qquad\Longleftrightarrow\qquad 
n\lambda_T^{3}\sim 1\;( {\rm 3D}),\;
\sigma\lambda_T^{2}\sim 1\;( {\rm 2D}),
\]
where \(n\) (\(\sigma\)) denotes the volume (area) density.  

“High’’ means **high compared with this quantum‑degeneracy scale**, not necessarily hundreds of kelvins. *In the momentum representation*

 } .

\]

Equivalently, the two kernels are related through the unitary change of basis:
\[

          \langle x|p\rangle\;\phi(p,p')\;\langle p'|x'\rangle ,
\qquad

\tag{3}
\]

\[

\]

**(b)   Zero and negative absolute temperature**

*Absolute zero.*   
Thermodynamic temperature is defined through the relation  

\[
\frac{1}{T}= \left(\frac{\partial S}{\partial U}\right)_V ,
\]

where \(S\) is the entropy and \(U\) the internal energy.  
The *absolute zero* (\(T=0\) K) is the limiting state in which the entropy attains its minimal possible value (conventionally chosen as zero) and no further removal of heat is possible. It is the lower bound imposed by the Third Law of Thermodynamics.

*Negative absolute temperature.*    
If a physical system possesses a **bounded energy spectrum**, the entropy may start to decrease when the internal energy exceeds the value that gives maximal disorder. From the definition above this yields  

\[
\frac{\partial S}{\partial U}<0\quad\Longrightarrow\quad T<0 .
\]

Thus a negative temperature does **not** lie below zero on any ordinary scale; it is hotter than any positive temperature because adding energy reduces the number of available microstates.

*A concrete realisation.*

Consider a collection of nuclear (or electronic) spins placed in a static magnetic field \(H\). Their Hamiltonian is  

\[
\mathcal H = -\mu H\sum_{i}s_i^z ,
\]

with only two energies: low‑energy “spin‑up’’ (\(+\tfrac12\)) and high‑energy “spin‑down’’ (\(-\tfrac12\)).  

1. In equilibrium with a cold lattice the majority occupy the low‑energy level ⇒ \(T>0\).

assistantfinalThe Carnot cycle consists of  

* Isothermal expansion at the high temperature \(T_{H}\)  
* Reversible adiabatic expansion down to the low temperature \(T_{C}\)  
* Isothermal compression at \(T_{C}\)   
* Reversible adiabatic compression back to the initial state.

Let one mole of an ideal gas perform the cycle.  
Denote the four vertices by  

\[
A:(T_{H},V_1)\qquad 
B:(T_{H},V_2)\qquad 
C:(T_{C},V_3)\qquad 
D:(T_{C},V_4)
\]

with \(V_2>V_1,\;V_3>V_4\).

---

### 1. Relations imposed by the adiabats  

For a reversible adiabatic process of an ideal gas,

\[
TV^{\gamma-1}= {\rm const},
\qquad\text{where }\;\gamma=\frac{C_P}{C_V}.
\]

Hence  

\[
T_{H}V_2^{\,\gamma-1}=T_{C}V_3^{\,\gamma-1}
      \Longrightarrow V_3=
        V_2\Bigl(\tfrac{T_{H}}{T_{C}}\Bigr)^{\!\frac{1}{\gamma-1}},
\]
\[
T_{C}V_4^{\,\gamma-1}=T_{H}V_1^{\,\gamma-1}
      \Longrightarrow V_4=
        V_1\Bigl(\tfrac{T_{C}}{T_{H}}\Bigr)^{\!\frac{1}{\gamma-1}} .
\]

These relations involve the specific‑heat ratio \(\gamma\); therefore the **shape** of the adiabats depends on whether the gas is monatomic (\(\gamma_{\mathrm{mono}}=5/3\)) or diatomic (\(\gamma_{\mathrm{di}}=7/5\)).  

Nevertheless, the ratio \(V_2/V_1\) – i.e., how far the system expands during the hot isotherm – remains a freely choosable parameter of the cycle and is taken to be the same for the two gases when comparing their performances.

---

### 2. Work performed during each segment  

Because the internal energy of an ideal gas depends only on temperature,
the heat exchanged during any isothermal step equals the work done in that step:

\[
\begin{aligned}
W_{AB}&=nRT_{H}\ln\frac{V_2}{V_1},\\[2pt]
W_{CD}&=-\,nRT_{C}\ln\frac{V_3}{V_4}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Using the adiabatic relations above one finds  

\[
\frac{V_3}{V_4}= \frac{V_2}{V_1},
\]

so that the magnitudes of the logarithmic terms are identical.  

Work on the two adiabatic branches cancels out when summed together, leaving the **net work**

\[
W=nR\bigl(T_{H}-T_{C}\bigr)\ln\frac{V_2}{V_1}.
\tag{1}
\]

Equation (1) contains only universal constants (\(n,R,T_H,T_C\)) and the chosen volume ratio \(V_2/V_1\); it does **not** contain \(\gamma\). Consequently the net work produced by one mole of gas in a Carnot cycle is independent of whether the gas is monatomic or diatomic.

---

### 3. Ratio of the works  

Let  

\[
W \quad\text{: work for a monatomic gas},\qquad
W'\quad\text{: work for a diatomic gas}.
\]

From Eq.(1),

\[
W=W',\qquad\Rightarrow\qquad\frac{W'}{W}=1 .
\]

---

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle \frac{W'}{W}=1 }
\]

assistantfinal**Solution**

A Frenkel‑type defect consists of removing an atom from its normal lattice site and putting it into an otherwise empty interstitial position.  
There are \(N\) ordinary lattice sites and exactly the same number \(N\) of possible interstitial places.  

Denote by \(n\;(0<n<N)\) the number of atoms that have been transferred to interstitial sites (the number of “defect pairs’’).   
All defects are assumed to be independent and non–interacting.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (a) Internal energy  

In the reference state (perfect crystal) the internal energy is taken as zero.  
Each transfer of an atom costs an amount of energy \(E\). Hence the total internal
energy contributed by the defects is simply  

\[
U = n\,E .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (b) Entropy  

The microscopic degeneracy comes from the different ways of choosing

* which \(n\) out of the \(N\) lattice sites become vacant,
* which \(n\) out of the \(N\) interstitial positions become occupied.

These choices are independent, therefore the number of distinct configurations is  

\[
\Omega=\binom{N}{n}\,\binom{N}{n}
      =\left[\frac{N!}{n!\,(N-n)!}\right]^2 .
\]

The Boltzmann entropy is  

\[
S=k_{\mathrm B}\ln\Omega 
  =2k_{\mathrm B}\Bigl[\ln N!- \ln n!-\ln (N-n)!\Bigr].
\]

For \(n\gg 1\) (and typically \(n\ll N\)) we use Stirling’s approximation  
\(\displaystyle \ln m!\simeq m\ln m-m+\tfrac12\ln(2\pi m)\).
Keeping only the dominant terms gives  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\frac{S}{k_{\mathrm B}}
&\simeq 2\bigl[N\ln N-n\ln n-(N-n)\ln (N-n)\bigr]\\[2mm]
&=2\Bigl[n\ln\frac{N}{n}+n\Bigr]\qquad (n\ll N)\\[2mm]
&\boxed{\;
    S\simeq 2k_{\mathrm B}\,n\Bigl[\ln\!\Bigl(\frac{N}{n}\Bigr)+1\Bigr]
     } .
\end{aligned}
\]

This is the required asymptotic expression (sub‑leading logarithmic terms
\( \sim \tfrac12\ln(2\pi N)\) may be added if desired).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (c) Equilibrium number of defects  

At temperature \(T\) the Helmholtz free energy is  

\[
F = U-TS = nE-T S .
\]

Equilibrium corresponds to the minimum of \(F\) with respect to \(n\):
\[
\frac{\partial F}{\partial n}=0
\;\Longrightarrow\;
E=T\frac{\partial S}{\partial n}.
\]

From the entropy found above,

\[
S = 2k_{\mathrm B}n\bigl[\ln(N/n)+1\bigr],
\quad\Rightarrow\quad
\frac{\partial S}{\partial n}=2k_{\mathrm B}\ln\!\Bigl(\frac{N}{n}\Bigr).
\]

Insert this into the extremum condition:

\[
E = T\;2k_{\mathrm B}\ln\!\Bigl(\frac{N}{n}\Bigr)
\;\Longrightarrow\;
\ln\!\Bigl(\frac{N}{n}\Bigr)=\frac{E}{2k_{\mathrm B}T}.
\]

Solving for \(n\),

\[
\boxed{
\; n_{\text{eq}} = N\exp\!\Bigl[-\frac{E}{2k_{\mathrm B}T}\Bigr]\;}
\qquad\text{(valid for }n\gg 1\text{).}
\]

Thus the equilibrium concentration of Frenkel defects is  

\[
c\equiv\frac{n_{\text{eq}}}{N}=e^{-\;E/(2k_{B}T)},
\]

an Arrhenius law with activation energy \(E/2\) per individual defect (because each
pair contributes two configurational degrees of freedom).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{l}
\text{(a)}\;U=nE \\[3pt]
\text{(b)}\;S\simeq 2k_{\rm B}\,n\bigl[\ln(N/n)+1\bigr] \\
\text{(c)}\;n=N\exp\!\bigl[-E/(2k_{\rm B}T)\bigr]
\end{array}}
\]

assistantfinal**(a)   Equality of the Gibbs‐free energies**

At the initial state the whole system (liquid + vapour) is in **thermal equilibrium** (\(T=T_{0}\)), **mechanical equilibrium**
(\(P=P_{0}\)) and **chemical equilibrium** (no net transfer of matter between the two phases).
When a very small amount \(\Delta N\) of material passes from the liquid into the vapour,
the external thermostat supplies exactly the heat \(\Delta Q\) necessary to keep the temperature
at \(T_{0}\) and the piston does work \({P}_{0}\,\Delta V\) so that the total pressure stays at
\(P_{0}\).

The first law for the combined system reads  

\[
\Delta U=\Delta Q-P_{0}\,\Delta V .
\]

Since the process is carried out reversibly at constant \(T_{0},\,P_{0}\),

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta G &=\Delta(U+P_{0}V-T_{0}S)\\
         &=\bigl[\Delta U+P_{0}\Delta V-T_{0}\Delta S\bigr]\\
         &=\Bigl[\Delta Q-P_{0}\Delta V+P_{0}\Delta V-
                T_{0}\Delta S\Bigr]=\Delta Q-T_{0}\Delta S .
\end{aligned}
\]

But for a reversible infinitesimal exchange of heat  
\(\displaystyle \Delta Q = T_{0}\,\Delta S\);
hence \(\boxed{\;\Delta G =0\;}\).

Consequently the **Gibbs free energy per mole** (the chemical potential) of the two
coexisting phases must be identical :

\[
\mu_{\ell}(T_{0},P_{0})=\mu_{g}(T_{0},P_{0})
\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad 
\boxed{\,g_\ell=g_g\,}.
\]

---

**(b)   Clausius – Clapeyron relation**

With the piston locked the volume is fixed, the surrounding bath is removed and a tiny
amount of heat \(\Delta Q\) is supplied.  Small variations \((\Delta T ,\Delta P)\) occur while a minute quantity
of liquid turns into vapour (or vice‑versa).   
Along the coexistence curve the molar Gibbs free energies remain equal;
therefore their differentials satisfy  

\[
dg_\ell=dg_g\quad\Rightarrow\quad
-s_\ell\,\Delta T+v_\ell\,\Delta P=
-s_g\,\Delta T+v_g\,\Delta P ,
\]

with \(s\;(v)\) denoting the molar entropy (volume).  Solving for the slope of the
phase‑boundary gives the **Clausius–Clapeyron equation**

\[
\boxed{\frac{\Delta P}{\Delta T}=%
      \frac{s_g-s_\ell}{\,v_g-v_\ell\,}} .
\]

If the vapour behaves ideally and its specific volume greatly exceeds those of the
condensed phases, one often writes   

\[
\frac{{\rm d}P}{{\rm d}T}= \frac{L}{T(v_g)}\approx
        \frac{L\,P}{R\,T^{2}},
\]
where \(L\) is the molar latent heat of the transition.

---

**(c)   Triple point of ammonia**

Data  

| Transition | Temperature (K) | Pressure (mm Hg) | Heat released to go “downward’’ |
|------------|-----------------|------------------|--------------------------------|
| Gas ⇌ Liquid (sat.) | \(T_{1}=220\) | \(P_{1}=262\) | \(L_{gl}=25\,400\ {\rm J~mol^{-1}}\) |
| Gas ⇌ Solid (sat.)  | \(T_{2}=180\) | \(P_{2}=8.8\) | \(L_{gs}=31\,200\ {\rm J~mol^{-1}}\) |

Treat the vapour as an ideal gas, hence \(v_g\simeq RT/P\) and the Clapeyron
equation reduces to  

\[
\frac{{\rm d}P}{{\rm d}T}= \frac{L\,P}{R\,T^{2}}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\frac{{\rm d}P}{P}= \frac{L}{R}\frac{{\rm d}T}{T^{2}} .
\]

Integrating from a known point \((T_i,P_i)\) to an arbitrary point \((T,P)\) gives  

\[
\ln\!\left(\frac{P}{P_i}\right)=\frac{L}{R}\!
          \left(\frac{1}{T_i}-\frac{1}{T}\right).\tag{1}
\]

Apply (1) separately to the two coexistence curves:

\[
\begin{aligned}
\ln P&=\ln P_{1}+ \frac{L_{gl}}{R}\Bigl(\frac{1}{T_{1}}-\frac{1}{T}\Bigr),
\\[2pt]
\ln P&=\ln P_{2}+ \frac{L_{gs}}{R}\Bigl(\frac{1}{T_{2}}-\frac{1}{T}\Bigr).
\end{aligned}
\]

Setting these right‑hand sides equal eliminates \(P\) and yields the temperature
of the common intersection (triple point):

\[
\frac{1}{T}= \frac{
     R\ln\!\left(P_{2}/P_{1}\right)-\bigl(L_{gl}/T_{1}-L_{gs}/T_{2}\bigr)}
    {L_{gs}-L_{gl}} .
\]

Insert the numerical values (\(R=8.314\ {\rm J\,mol^{-1}K^{-1}}\)):
\[
\begin{aligned}
L_{gl}/T_{1}&= \frac{25\,400}{220}=115.46,\\
L_{gs}/T_{2}&= \frac{31\,200}{180}=173.33,\\
R\ln(P_{2}/P_{1})&=8.314\;\ln\!\frac{8.8}{262}=8.314\times(-3.389)=-28.19 .
\end{aligned}
\]

Hence  

\[
\frac{1}{T}= \frac{-28.19- (115.46-173.33)}{31\,200-25\,400}
           =\frac{29.69}{5\,800}=0.00512\ {\rm K^{-1}},
\qquad
\boxed{T_{\text{tp}}\approx 1.95\times10^{2}\ {\rm K}} .
\]

Using this temperature in either version of (1) gives the corresponding pressure:

\[
\ln P =\ln 262+\frac{25\,400}{8.314}\Bigl(\frac{1}{220}-\frac{1}{195.4}\Bigr)
       =5.568-1.749 =3.82,
\]
so  

\[
\boxed{P_{\text{tp}}\approx e^{3.82}\ {\rm mm\,Hg}\;\approx\;4.5\times10^{1}\ {\rm mm\,Hg}} .
\]

(The value obtained from the solid–vapour branch is the same within rounding.)

assistantfinalFor one spin‑\( \tfrac12 \) placed in a uniform magnetic field **B**, the two possible orientations give the Zeeman energies  

\[
E_{\uparrow}= -\,mB ,\qquad 
E_{\downarrow}= +\,mB .
\]

At temperature \( \tau \) (\(k_{B}\tau\equiv k_{B}T\)) the Boltzmann weights are  

\[
w_\uparrow=e^{-\beta E_{\uparrow}}=e^{\beta mB},\qquad   
w_\downarrow=e^{-\beta E_{\downarrow}}=e^{-\beta mB},
\]
with \(\beta=\dfrac{1}{k_{B}\tau}\).

---

### Single–particle averages  

The single‑spin partition function  

\[
z=w_\uparrow+w_\downarrow = 2\cosh(\beta mB)
\]

gives the mean value of the spin variable  
\[
\sigma=
\begin{cases}
+1 & (\text{parallel}),\\[2pt]
-1 & (\text{antiparallel}),
\end{cases}
\]  

as  

\[
\langle\sigma\rangle =
\frac{(+1) w_\uparrow+(-1) w_\downarrow}{z}
      =\frac{e^{\beta mB}-e^{-\beta mB}}
            {e^{\beta mB}+e^{-\beta mB}}
      =\tanh(\beta mB).
\]

Because the magnetic moment of a spin pointing “up’’ contributes \(+m\) and “down’’ contributes \(-m\),

\[
\biggl\langle\frac{\mu}{m}\biggr\rangle =\langle\sigma\rangle .
\]

Hence the **fractional magnetisation** of a single spin,
\[
\frac{M}{Nm}= \langle\sigma\rangle ,
\]
is already known.

---

### Many non‑interacting spins  

Since the spins do not interact, the ensemble average over all \(N\) spins equals the single‑spin average:

\[
\boxed{
\frac{M}{Nm}= \tanh\!\Bigl(\frac{mB}{k_{B}\,\tau}\Bigr)}
\]

or equivalently,

\[
\frac{M}{Nm}= \tanh\!\bigl[\beta\,mB\bigr].
\]

In terms of the spin excess \(2s=(N_{\uparrow}-N_{\downarrow})\),

\[
\frac{2\langle s\rangle}{N}= \tanh\!\Bigl(\frac{mB}{k_{B}\tau}\Bigr),
\]

which is the required equilibrium value of the fractional magnetisation at temperature \( \tau \).

The electromagnetic field in a cavity may be treated as a collection of harmonic oscillators (photon modes).  
For each mode of frequency \( \nu\) the mean occupation number at temperature \(T\) is  

\[
\langle n_\nu\rangle=\frac{1}{e^{h\nu/k_{\!B}T}-1}.
\]

The energy per unit volume contributed by this mode is  

\[
u(\nu)\,{\rm d}\nu=
\underbrace{8\pi\,\frac{\nu^{2}}{c^{3}}\ {\rm d}\nu}_{\text{density of states}}
\times 
\underbrace{h\nu}_{\text{energy quantum}}
\times 
\underbrace{\langle n_\nu\rangle}_{\text{average occupancy}},
\]

so that  

\[
u(T)=\int_{0}^{\infty}
\frac{8\pi h \nu^{3}}{c^{3}}\,
\frac{{\rm d}\nu}{e^{h\nu/k_{\!B}T}-1 } .
\]

Introduce the dimensionless variable \(x=h\nu/k_{\!B}T\); then  

\[
u(T)=\frac{8\pi(k_{\!B}T)^{4}}{(hc)^{3}}
      \int_{0}^{\infty}\!\frac{x^{3}}{{\rm e}^{x}-1}\,dx .
\]

The integral evaluates to \(\displaystyle \int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{x^{3}}{e^{x}-1}\,dx=\frac{\pi^{4}}{15}\).
Hence  

\[
\boxed{\,\frac{U}{V}=u(T)=A\,T^{4}},\qquad   
A=\frac{8\pi^{5}k_{\!B}^{4}}{15\,h^{3}c^{3}} ,
\]
which shows that the **energy density of black–body radiation varies as \(T^{4}\)**.

Radiation inside the cavity is isotropic.  For an element of solid angle \(d\Omega\)
the intensity crossing a surface element \(dS\) is \((c/4\pi)u(T)d\Omega\cos\theta\),
where \(\theta\) is the angle between the ray direction and the normal.
Integrating over all outward directions (\(0\le\theta\le\pi/2\), \(0\le\phi<2\pi\))

\[
J_{U}= \int I\cos\theta\,d\Omega
     =\frac{c}{4\pi}u(T)\,\int_{0}^{2\pi}\!\!d\phi
        \int_{0}^{\pi/2}\!\!\cos\theta\sin\theta\,d\theta
     =\frac{c}{4}\,u(T).
\]

Since \(u(T)=AT^{4}\),

\(B\) is the familiar **Stefan–Boltzmann constant** divided by four.

Z_{N}=Z_{1}^{\,N},
\qquad   
\ln Z_{N}=N\ln Z_{1}.
\]

\[
F=-k_{\rm B}T\ln Z_{N}=-
NK_{\rm B}T\bigl[\ln A+\ln V\bigr],
\quad 
A\equiv\frac{8\pi}{h^{3}( \beta c)^{3}} .
\]

\[
P=-\left(\frac{\partial F}{\partial V}\right)_{T,N}
   = NK_{\rm B}T\;\frac{1}{V}
   =\frac{Nk_{\rm B}T}{V}.
\]

\[
\boxed{PV=N K_{\rm B}T } .
\]

*Internal energy*

Using  

\[
U=-\frac{\partial\ln Z_{N}}{\partial\beta},
\]

and noting that only the factor \((\beta)^{-3}\) inside \(Z_{1}\) carries \(\beta\),

\[
\begin{aligned}
\ln Z_{N}&=N\!\left[\ln\!\Bigl(\frac{8\pi V}{h^{3}c^{3}}\Bigr)-3\ln\beta\right],\\[2mm]
\frac{\partial\ln Z_{N}}{\partial\beta}&=
N\!\left(-\frac{3}{\beta}\right),
\end{aligned}
\]

so  

\[
U=-\frac{\partial\ln Z_{N}}{\partial\beta}
   =\frac{3N}{\beta}=3Nk_{\rm B}T .
\]

Consequently  

\[
\boxed{U=3Nk_{\rm B}T},\qquad 
\boxed{P=\frac13\frac{U}{V}} .

The four stages of the cycle are  

\[
\begin{array}{ll}

      \Delta T=+\delta T .
\end{array}
\]

Because the two non‑isothermal branches are **adiabatic**, all the heat exchange occurs on the two isobars :

* \(q_{H}=nL_{v}\) (the latent heat taken from the hot reservoir);
* \(q_{C}<0\) (the latent heat delivered to the cold reservoir).

In the \(P\!-\!V\) plane the trajectory is almost a rectangle whose sides are  

\[
\Delta V = V_{2}-V_{1}=n\,(v_{g}-v_{\ell}),\qquad    
\Delta p = p_{v}-p_{c},
\]

where \(v_{g}\;(=\bar V _{\rm g})\) and \(v_{\ell}\;(=\bar V _{\rm l})\) are the molar volumes of the vapour and the liquid, respectively.  
(The change of volume on the two adiabats is negligible compared with \(\Delta V\) because \(\Delta T\) is assumed very small.)

Consequently the net mechanical work produced in one complete circuit is simply the area of that rectangle,

\[
W_{\mathrm {net}}=
\oint p\,\mathrm dV\simeq \Delta p\,\Delta V
          =\Delta p\;n\bigl(v_{g}-v_{\ell}\bigr).
\]

The thermal efficiency is therefore  

\[
\boxed{
\eta\equiv\frac{W_{\mathrm {net}}}{q_{H}}
        =\frac{n\,(v_{g}-v_{\ell})\,\Delta p}{nL_{v}}
        =\frac{(v_{g}-v_{\ell})\,\Delta p}{L_{v}}\;}
\tag{1}
\]

which is valid to first order in the small quantities \(\Delta p\) and \(\Delta T\).

For any *reversible* Carnot engine working between two reservoirs at absolute
temperatures \(T\) (hot) and \(T-\Delta T\) (cold) the efficiency is dictated
solely by these temperatures; it does **not** depend on the particular way the
engine operates.  This follows directly from the Second Law: if two such
engines had different efficiencies, their combination would constitute a
perpetual‐motion machine of the second kind. Hence every reversible engine
between the same pair of temperatures has the common efficiency

\[
\eta_{\text{Carnot}}=\frac{T-(T-\Delta T)}{T}= \frac{\Delta T}{T}.
\tag{2}
\]

\[

\boxed{
\frac{{\rm d}p_{v}}{{\rm d}T}= \frac{L_{v}}{T\;\bigl(v_{g}-v_{\ell}\bigr)}

\]

For a macroscopic system we take \(N\gg 1\) and replace \(N-1\simeq N\):

\[

\[
\begin{aligned}
\sigma &=\ln\Bigl[\frac{(n+N)!}{n!\,N!}\Bigr]\\[2mm]
       &\simeq (n+N)\ln (n+N)-(n+N)
            -\big[n\ln n-n\big]-\big[N\ln N-N\big] \\[2mm]
       &= (n+N)\ln (n+N)-n\ln n-N\ln N .
\end{aligned}
\]

\qquad\text{i.e. }\;U=N\hbar\omega\,x .

and the one‑particle energy levels are

\[

             =\frac{\hbar ^{2}}{2m}

### (a) Derivation of \(v^{2}= \displaystyle\frac{{\rm d}p}{{\rm d}\rho }\)

For a perfect (inviscid, non‑conductive) fluid the governing equations are  

*Continuity*

\[
\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t}+ \boldsymbol\nabla\!\cdot(\rho\mathbf u)=0 ,
\tag{1}
\]

*Euler’s momentum equation*

\[
\rho\Bigl[\frac{\partial \mathbf u}{\partial t}+ (\mathbf u\!\cdot\! \boldsymbol\nabla)\mathbf u\Bigr]
   +\boldsymbol\nabla p =0 .
\tag{2}
\]

Consider a **small perturbation** about a uniform equilibrium state  
\((\rho_0 ,\,p_0 ,\,\mathbf u_0=\mathbf 0 )\):

\[
\rho =\rho _0+\rho ',\qquad 
p=p_{0}+p',\qquad 
\mathbf u =\mathbf u' ,
\]

where primed quantities satisfy \(|\rho '|,\ |p'|,\ |\mathbf u'|\ll \rho_0,p_0\).
Keeping only first–order terms we obtain the **linearised** equations:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{\partial \rho'}{\partial t}+ \rho_0\,\boldsymbol\nabla\!\cdot\mathbf u'=0,
\\[3pt]
&\rho_0\frac{\partial \mathbf u'}{\partial t}+ \boldsymbol\nabla p'=0 .
\end{aligned}}
\tag{3}
\]

The thermodynamic relation between the pressure and density fluctuations follows from the fact that the disturbance propagates faster than any thermal diffusion – i.e. it is essentially **adiabatic or isothermal**, but locally the functional dependence can be written as  

\[
p'=c^{2}_{s}\,\rho',
\qquad\text{with }c_{s}^{2}\equiv\left.\frac{{\rm d}p}{{\rm d}\rho}\right|_{\!*},
\tag{4}
\]

the derivative being taken along the appropriate process path (isothermal, adiabatic,…).

Take the time derivative of the continuity equation (first line of (3)) and use the divergence of the momentum equation (second line of (3)) :

\[
\frac{\partial ^2\rho'}{\partial t^{2}}+ \rho_0\,
      \boldsymbol\nabla\!\cdot\frac{\partial \mathbf u'}{\partial t}=0,
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\frac{\partial ^2\rho'}{\partial t^{2}}-
        \boldsymbol\nabla^{2}p'=0 .
\]

Now substitute (4): \(p'=c_{s}^{2}\rho'\),

\[
\frac{\partial ^2\rho'}{\partial t^{2}}-
       c_{s}^{2}\,\boldsymbol\nabla^{2}\rho'=0 .
\]

This is the standard wave equation whose propagation speed is  

\[
\boxed{\,v^{2}=c_{s}^{2}= \frac{{\rm d}p}{{\rm d}\rho}\,}.
\]

Thus the square of the acoustic velocity equals the slope of the \(p-\rho\) curve evaluated on the relevant thermodynamic branch.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (b) Speed of sound in an ideal gas  

An ideal gas obeys  

\[
p=\rho R T ,\qquad R=\frac{R_{\mathrm u}}{M}
\tag{5}
\]

\(R\) being the specific gas constant (for dry air \(R\simeq 287~\text{J kg}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}\)).  

#### • Isothermal compression (\(T={\rm const}\))

From (5) with \(T\) fixed,

\[
p\propto\rho\;\Rightarrow\;
\frac{{\rm d}p}{{\rm d}\rho}=RT .
\]

Hence  

\[
\boxed{v_{\text{iso}}=\sqrt{RT}}\; .
\tag{6}
\]

#### • Adiabatic compression  

Adiabatic processes follow \(p\rho^{-\gamma}= {\rm const}\) (\(\gamma=C_p/C_v\)). Differentiating,

\[
p = K\rho^\gamma\;\Longrightarrow\;
\frac{{\rm d}p}{{\rm d}\rho}= \gamma K\rho^{\gamma-1}= \gamma\frac{p}{\rho}
          =\gamma RT .
\]

Therefore  

\[
\boxed{v_{\text{adia}}=\sqrt{\gamma RT}}\; .
\tag{7}
\]

These formulas hold pointwise; inserting the ambient temperature yields the local sound speed.

At room conditions (approximately \(T=300\ \text{K}\)), using \(R=287\ \text{J kg}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}\) and \(\gamma_{\text{air}}\approx1.40\),

\[

v_{\text{iso}} &=\sqrt{RT}
               =\sqrt{287\times300}
               \approx 2.93\times10^{2}\ \text{m s}^{-1}, \\[4pt]
v_{\text{adia}}&=\sqrt{\gamma RT}
                =\sqrt{1.40\times287\times300}
                \approx 3.47\times10^{2}\ \text{m s}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}

For each site three microscopic possibilities exist  

* empty : \(n=0\) , energy \(0\);  

* occupied in “strong’’ state : \(n=1\) , binding energy \(-\varepsilon _0\);  

* occupied in “weak’’ state : \(n=1\) , binding energy \(-\tfrac12\varepsilon _0\).

Because the gas acts as a **pressure‑reservoir** its chemical potential is fixed,
and the whole system is kept at a uniform temperature \(T\).
Hence the appropriate thermodynamic description is the **grand–canonical ensemble**
for a single site.  

---

### Grand‑partition function of one site  

With the convention that adding a particle lowers the grand‑potential by \(\mu\),
the Boltzmann weight of a configuration containing a molecule in state \(i\)
is  

\[
\exp\!\bigl[-\beta\,(H_i-\mu N_i)\bigr]
      =\exp\!\bigl[-\beta(-\varepsilon_i-\mu)\bigr]
      =\exp\!\bigl[\beta(\mu+\varepsilon_i)\bigr],
\qquad \beta\equiv\frac1{k_\mathrm B T},
\]

where \(\varepsilon_1=\varepsilon_0\) (strong) and \(\varepsilon_2=\varepsilon_0/2\) (weak).

Therefore the single‑site grand‑partition function reads  

\[
\Xi=
1+
e^{\beta(\mu+\varepsilon_0)}+
e^{\beta\bigl(\mu+\varepsilon_0/2\bigr)} .
\tag{1}
\]

---

### Average occupation (coverage)

The mean number of adsorbed molecules per site – the fractional coverage \(\theta\) –
is obtained from  

\[
\theta\equiv\langle n\rangle =
\frac{
e^{\beta(\mu+\varepsilon_0)}+
e^{\beta\bigl(\mu+\varepsilon_0/2\bigr)}
}{
\;1+
e^{\beta(\mu+\varepsilon_0)}+
e^{\beta\bigl(\mu+\varepsilon_0/2\bigr)}\;
}.
\tag{2}
\]

Every occupied state contributes exactly one molecule irrespective of whether it
lies in the strong or weak well.

---

### Introducing the gas‐phase pressure

For an ideal gas the chemical potential at temperature \(T\) and pressure \(P\) is  

\[
\mu(T,P)=\mu^{\circ}(T)+k_{\!B}T\ln\!\frac{P}{P^{\circ}},
\]

with some convenient standard pressure \(P^{\circ}\) (often \(1~\text{bar}\)).
Writing  

\[
z\equiv e^{\beta\mu}=e^{\beta\mu^{\circ}(T)}\,
        \frac{P}{P^{\circ}},
\]

eqs. (1)–(2) become  

\[
\theta(T,P)=
\frac{ z\,e^{\beta\varepsilon_0}+z\,e^{\beta\varepsilon_0/2} }
     { 1+z\,e^{\beta\varepsilon_0}+z\,e^{\beta\varepsilon_0/2} } .
\tag{3}
\]

It is convenient to collect the temperature‑dependent factors into an **effective
Langmuir constant**

\[
K_{\rm eff}(T)\equiv e^{\beta\mu^{\circ}(T)}
                 \Bigl[e^{\beta\varepsilon_0}+e^{\beta\varepsilon_0/2}\Bigr].
\]

Using this definition,

\[
\boxed{\;
\theta(T,P)=\frac{K_{\rm eff}(T)\;(P/P^{\circ})}
                {1+K_{\rm eff}(T)\;(P/P^{\circ})}\;} .
\tag{4}
\]

Equation (4) gives the desired coverage as a simple Langmuir‑type isotherm whose
“adsorption strength’’ is the sum of contributions from the two distinct binding
states. It explicitly displays how the fraction of covered sites grows with
increasing pressure and decreases with rising temperature through the factor
\(K_{\rm eff}(T)=\exp[\beta(\mu^{\circ}(T))]\,[\exp(\beta\varepsilon_0)+\exp(\beta\varepsilon_0/2)]\).
